Posts.Content: I had salvage radiation in 2007, after a prostatectomy in 2006. It has apparently cured me. My PSA has been undetectable since September of that year. I have no lingering side effects. For me, the treatments were very easy. I had no fatigue (but I was pretty young, so that might have had something to do with it) and I didn't miss any work. I developed a slight bowel issue towards the end of the two months, but it resolved itself within a matter of weeks once the treatments ended. I would agree with the posters who say that the lower the PSA when starting salvage, the better. Best of luck to your dad.

Posts.Title: Diet

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I don't think anyone really knows the answer to this. Genetics seems to be the main factor. So I'd simply follow the old adage that you can have anything you want "in moderation." I agree with Highlander. Don't get overly anxious about all this. It sounds like you have the right general idea. I think maintaining a healthy weight is important, and if you're doing that you're probably not eating a ton of cheeseburgers and milkshakes. If you want to get more strict about it, there are cookbooks for fighting cancer. But I think you've got the gist of it--more plant-based foods, less red meat. You'll be healthier on multiple fronts, especially if you exercise. Just my opinion, of course. I recently did genetic testing through 23andMe. It was fascinating to go through my results. From a bit of saliva, the test accurately showed my eye color, blood type, hair curliness, lactose intolerance, earwax type, and caffeine metabolism (quick!). But near the top of the risks list was prostate cancer, in bold red letters. Mind you, the testing firm had no idea I had been diagnosed. But my genetics had loaded the gun and probably pulled the trigger on me in terms of prostate cancer. I imagine a vegan diet and all the extreme workouts in the world would not have changed the fact that I would be diagnosed. However...if I had been obese, I think it's possible that my cancer might have been more aggressive. Studies have shown a correlation there. 23andMe showed my risk of prostate cancer to be 2.86 times the average man's. I had markers for high risk on 10 out of 12 genes known to be associated with prostate cancer. At this point, I seem to have taken care of my prostate cancer. Now I'm concentrating on another genetic risk identified by 23andMe: coronary heart disease. It is my highest risk on the 23andMe disease list. I'm also at increased genetic risk of Alzheimer's (1.98x the general population), rheumatoid arthritis, thromboembolism, psoriasis, colorectal cancer, stomach cancer, esophogeal cancer, and multiple sclerosis. But of all those, the biggest danger and the one I can do the most about is heart disease. So I joined Weight Watchers (I'm a lifetime member--lost 35 lbs), started cycling, and cutting out a lot of red meat and dairy. We'll see how it goes. One thing's for sure. I feel a lot better these days. Weight Watchers could help you make healthy eating choices without feeling deprived. It did for me. I wish you well.

Posts.Title: Diet

Posts.Content: I had radiation proctitis. It came on during the last couple of weeks of treatment, getting a little worse each day. My radiation oncologist gave me a prescription for Proctofoam, a topical analgesic foam (pretty easy to apply) that really helped. Like a fire extinguisher. About 2 weeks or so after treatment, the proctitis dropped off signifcantly, and within a couple of months was gone completely. A colonoscopy several years later did not reveal any visible damage, nor did I have any polyps or tumors. I blogged about my proctitis! http://pcabefore50.blogspot.com/search/label/proctitis I wish you well. This too shall pass.

Posts.Title: Radiation Proctitis

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ThatBiopsyHurt Personally, I wouldn't let a guy that's only done 25 robotics anywhere near my prostate. If he's done several hundred open procedures, you might want to consider going that way if you are absolutely tied to this guy because of your insurance. Having a lot of experience doing opens doesn't translate into being a good robotic surgeon. It's a whole different ball game and the learning experience of the robot is quite steep, on the order of several hundred procedures. The first thing I would do is find out what his outcomes are. He should have that information. If they aren't good, I'd be doing battle with my insurance company to get me to a guy who's outcomes are good. No do-overs here. Good luck to you. I agree. I had a surgeon who was very experienced in open procedures, but totally inexperienced with Da Vinci, and I had an 8 hour operation (double that of a normal robotic procedure) with sub-optimal results. In hindsight, I would have just had him do a traditional prostatectomy, or sought out an experienced Da Vinci surgeon. Maybe I would have had clean margins and no need for radiation. The learning curve is long.

Posts.Content: What seems to matter are the exact stage beyond just IV, and the age of the patient. Younger patients with no lymph node involvement (T4N0M0) or mets had a much higher survival rate than older patients with mets http://www.casa.gov.au/wcmswr/_asset...4_prostate.pdf Here's another study with similar results from the US: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20620410

Posts.Content: Lildog, I don't know if the pathologist noted the size of the positive margins, but they were at the apex and left lobe: http://pcabefore50.blogspot.com/2008...-prostate.html I will try to remember to dig out my medical record and take a look for more details. An interesting tidbit--the surgeon had a false memory of negative margins. He verbally told me that, and when it was time to refer me to radiation and medical oncologists, he put at Post-It on the outside of my file saying "neg margins". But they weren't. It was a surprise when the first specialist I visited told me, after looking at the pathology report, that my margins were positive. That was actually welcome news, because I knew that it increased the likelihood of success with radiation if there was a local explanation for my rising PSA. Normally you want to hear that your margins are negative. But if your PSA is rising, positive margins indicate that the reason might still be in the prostate bed--and the disease still potentially curable. Originally Posted by LILDOG Congrats Replicant ! If you don't mine me asking how large were your positive margins and at what location of the prostate just curious ? Again GOD BLESS wish you well in the future !

Posts.Title: 8 years post SRT

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by goatts How long does it take to recover from one radiation treatment. How long before you can go back to work? Thanks Tom From one treatment? You shouldn't notice anything from an individual treatment. After a number of treatments you may start to have some fatigue or bowel issues. I did not experience fatigue. I kept working and just built the treatments into my work week. Each one only took a few minutes, maybe half an hour including waiting, getting positioned on the table, etc. I did have some bowel issues that started towards the end of the treatments, but they resolved within a few weeks, and were never serious enough to keep me from normal activities. My experience was with radiation as a secondary (salvage) treatment, but I can't imagine why having it as a primary treatment would be much different in terms of feeling something after an individual radiation session. You really don't feel anything but boredom from a treatment. The dose each time is pretty small, but they add up to a therapeutic level over time.

Posts.Title: Radiation recovery time

Posts.Content: great report. My history is very similar to your husband's: G7 cancer diagnosed in my 40's, RP, positive margin, initial PSA undetectable but rising thereafter. I also had SRT without ADT. I had some bowel issues (pain/discomfort during bowel movements) that turned about to be acute radiation proctitis. Treated with a topical (well, sort of topical, if you know what I mean) analgesic foam. Went on a low-residue diet. The proctitis resolved on its own within a few weeks after radiation treatments ceased. My PSA never rose in the subsequent 13+ years--although I'm knocking on wood because I had a blood draw last week as part of a physical. Best of luck to you and your husband!

Posts.Content: Hi Jaha. Sounds like you're doing pretty well..PSA is only creeping up. I gather you decided against salvage radiation? Also, didn't you have an issue with low white blood cell count (leukopenia) or am I thinking of someone else? It's good to hear from you. Originally Posted by jaha Hi Replicant Thanks for your inquiry, I had my last Lupron injection April 2013, at that point my Psa was 0.074 and testosterone was 0.2. Since then my psa remained about <0.1 until November when it crept up to 0.2, by April this year it had gone up to 0.3 this was in line with the rise in testosterone. My urologist has recommended I now continue with Lupron, so I will have an injection within the next week, so it's back to hot flushes etc. I have also been on Advodart for the last 18 months, which has restricted the amount of free testosterone.

Posts.Content: Take a group of 100 men, PSA 4-6, Gleason 3+4=7. According to the Partin tables, 66 of them should have organ-confined disease. According to the Han tables, out of that group, 58 (88%) should be free of recurrence at 10 years. The men who had NON-organ confined disease number 34. According to the Han tables, 22 (66%) should be free of recurrence at 10 years. So out of the intial group, we have 58+22=80 who are recurrence-free at the 10 year mark from surgery. 80% of all the 3+4 guys. That's just guys in the PSA range of 4-6 or 4-10. When Epstein made his remark, he was talking about the total, not a subgroup based on PSA. He could have also been speaking rather loosely about "cure". When you look at prostate-cancer specific mortality, it is less than 10% for 3+4=7 at the 15 year mark. PCSM is not the same as being cured. It just means you didn't die from prostate cancer during that time. http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...prostatectomy/ Originally Posted by pjr Hi All, I'm wondering if anyone could enlighten me on how to understand what I think are odd stats that I read on the Johns Hopkins website. I may be missing the obvious, so any thoughts would be helpful! First, in the winter 2014 issue of their "Prostate Discovery Magazine," (article on tweaking the Gleason system) they write: "In the past, any Gleason pattern 4 tumor was considered aggressive," says Epstein. "But we showed that Gleason score 3+4=7 cancer has a very favorable prognosis, with over 90 percent of men cured after radical prostatectomy." http://urology.jhu.edu/newsletter/20...er_2014_19.php Then I look at the Han Table. http://urology.jhu.edu/prostate/han_tables.php Han Table for PSA 4-6; Gleason 3+4; Clinical T1c 3 years after surgery: 3% (1-10) 5 years after surgery: 5% (2-16) 7 years after surgery: 7% (2-23) 10 years after surgery:10% (3-2 Here's the Han Table with data after surgery. Han Table for PSA 4-6; Gleason 3+4; Organ confined 3 years after surgery: 4% (1-10) 5 years after surgery: 6% (2-17) 7 years after surgery: 9% (3-24) 10 years after surgery: 12% (4-29) First, these numbers are pretty consistent with Epstein's quote, but I don't understand the slightly higher percentages given for after surgery if it's known to be organ confined. Then, here's the Han table if it's not organ confined: Han Table for PSA 4-6; Gleason 3+4; Organ confined 3 years after surgery: 12% (5-30) 5 years after surgery: 19% (7-45) 7 years after surgery: 27% (11-59) 10 years after surgery: 34% (14-6 Finally, Partin Table for Clinical T1c; PSA 4-6; Gleason 3+4 lists the probability of organ confined to 66%. http://urology.jhu.edu/prostate/partin_tables.php Maybe I'm splitting hairs here, but I don't understand how people can quote a 90% cure rate for 3+4 when only 66% are predicted to be organ confined; and if it's not organ confined, then there's a 35% chance of recurrence. Can anyone help me understand that? It seems to have pretty important implications in terms of treatment decisions.... Thanks!! Mary

Posts.Content: Ali, sorry to hear it's prostate cancer. Can you clarify the stage? It's usually T2a, T2b, T3a, and so forth. I'm guessing you meant stage T2 something. There is a description of the various stages here: http://www.phoenix5.org/Infolink/ClinicalStaging.html and on other sites. I recommend getting a copy of the biopsy pathology report. It will have plenty of valuable information that you can use in conjunction with John (az4peak)'s sticky message at the top of this forum "What every newly diagnosed PCa patient MUST know" You mentioned HIFU. My impression of HIFU is that it is showing promise in low to intermediate risk cancer. In my layperson's view, that does not include Gleason 9, PSA 15 cancer. I base this view, that HIFU is not appropriate in high risk cases, from my reading of several study abstracts, including two separate Italian studies: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19260381 and http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19081465 ; a Japanese study of 517 men : http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19863624 , a French study of 119 men: http://www.springerlink.com/content/2885g36408825j26/ , from a HIFU manufacturer, Edap: http://www.edap-tms.com/uploads/pdf/..._robertson.pdf , and multiple other sources. That's not to say you should not investigate HIFU on your own, or substitute my thoughts on the matter for qualified medical advice. I would consult specialists in each treatment modality available to you. A medical oncologist who specializes in prostate cancer, if you can find one close to you, could be a valuable asset. If you can post the specifics of your husband's biopsy report, there are others here who can provide more targeted assistance. You could also take the information from the report and plug it into the calcultor at the Memorial Sloan Kettering site, http://nomograms.org , to get various probabilities. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: If he has prostate cancer, can he have radiation again?

Posts.Content: Even if BPH isn't likely, PSA might still be elevated from prostatitis. As for treatments, that's a big question, and there is no one single answer. Radiation can indeed treat more than just the prostate itself, if local spread is suspected. It can also be done after surgery, on an adjuvant or salvage basis. I don't know the answer about whether his previous radiation would rule out prostate radiation. That would be a good question for a radiation oncologist, and should your husband be diagnosed, I would definitely consult one in addition to the urologist and a medical oncologist. If he has a biopsy, and if it is positive for cancer, it will provide valuable information that will help the physician(s) estimate clinical stage and recommend appropriate treatment. Be sure to read the sticky post at the top of this forum by az4peaks for the newly diagnosed. And I recommend "Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" (2007 ed.) Best wishes.

Posts.Content: I agree with mkane09. I didn't push myself, and I still got a hernia (right where the main incision hit my navel.) It was no big deal to fix, but I could have done without the hassle. Even though the incisions may be small, what goes on underneath is still major surgery. I've started to get a lot more physically active over the past 2 years. I'm 51. I had surgery at 43. I think you will be able to catch up on your fitness. You'll just need to ease back into activities.

Posts.Content: There's every reason to believe you'll do just fine. Best of luck to you, from one youngster (43) with Gleason 7 to another. Originally Posted by OTCHU Hello everybody Maybe some people did read my case few weeks ago but here are the data: I am 41 years old. PC detected in October 2012 Gleason 7: < = 5% After 2 opinions just to be sure, I decided to have the prostate remove I am going to have a radical perineal prostatectomy (RPP) at the CTCA (Cancer treatment center of America) at Philly the 8th January. Doctor Sloane will do the surgery. The CTCA is wonderful and I recommend it to everybody. Hes going to try to do the nerves sparing but not sure at 100% that will be possible (depend if the cancer will be in this area or not). I am very very very nervous right now. Still can not believe that does happen to me at 41 years old. But will take the best of what will happen from now. I will keep you posted guys .... good luck to everybody

Posts.Title: Interesting link regarding cancet vaccines.

Posts.Content: Hi. You are fairly young, but I was diagnosed at 43 after suspecting it for years. And like you, I had Gleason 3+4. What is your PSA history? Those options you listed are correct--sort of. But there are more variations than those you listed. You would have the option of traditional surgery (non-robot) if you want, but most guys go for the robot these days if it's available. You need to have an experienced surgeon, though, with hundreds of robotic procedures done already and good results. I had both surgery (robotic) and radiation, because my PSA came back after surgery. Surgery was the hardest to recover from and left me with some side effects. Mainly I'm left with some erectile problems although I can function fine with medication. Radiation didn't leave me with ANY long term side effects--I'm now over 5 years out from the end of radiation. However, one thing us young guys need to worry a little about with radiation is secondary tumors. The risk isn't extreme, but it is present, and we have a very long life ahead of us with plenty of time for a radiation-induced cancer to get going. I'm very aware that I should not skip recommended screening colonoscopies, for example. (I just had my first colonoscopy and it was fine. No cancer, no polyps, no sign of radiation damage.) Surgery has a long, well-known history of success, but as you know by now, some sexual side effects are likely, and how severe they will be is not possible to predict beforehand. However, if your surgeon can spare the nerve bundles, your youth will be an advantage in regaining erections. You may also have some problems with continence (holding your urine) and it's likely you will have to wear some kind of pads for a short time after surgery. How long and how severe the urinary problem will be is also impossible to predict ahead of time. I think most men are dry within a matter of weeks or months, but some have long term problems. **You need to find the best prostate surgeon you can if you choose surgery** Freezing is called cryotherapy. My father had it 20 or so years ago and it apparently cured his cancer. His PSA never came back. It fell out of favor for a while, due to extreme sexual side effects, but I think it's regained some popularity and techniques have probably gotten better. Radiation is not free from side effects. A lot of guys get a gradual erectile problem in the years after radiation. Sometimes you can have urinary side effects. The main advantage to radiation, in my book, is that it's a very easy treatment to tolerate. The treatments themselves are painless and non-invasive (if you have external radiation). You could also have seeds (brachytherapy) or a combination of external radiation and brachytherapy. I should add that I had some bowel problems after radiation--called radiation proctitis. But they got better and vanished within a matter of weeks. Some guys have longer term bowel issues after external radiation. Don't let the side effects scare you away from treating your cancer. You can't have erections or go to the bathroom in a coffin, after all. Try to focus on getting rid of the cancer by finding a treatment that is in line with your preferences and values, and find the best doctor you can who performs that treatment. Posts.Title: biopsy result yesterday ... I have prostate cancer at 40 years old. Need advices

Posts.Content: Hi. You are fairly young, but I was diagnosed at 43 after suspecting it for years. And like you, I had Gleason 3+4. What is your PSA history? Those options you listed are correct--sort of. But there are more variations than those you listed. You would have the option of traditional surgery (non-robot) if you want, but most guys go for the robot these days if it's available. You need to have an experienced surgeon, though, with hundreds of robotic procedures done already and good results. I had both surgery (robotic) and radiation, because my PSA came back after surgery. Surgery was the hardest to recover from and left me with some side effects. Mainly I'm left with some erectile problems although I can function fine with medication. Radiation didn't leave me with ANY long term side effects--I'm now over 5 years out from the end of radiation. However, one thing us young guys need to worry a little about with radiation is secondary tumors. The risk isn't extreme, but it is present, and we have a very long life ahead of us with plenty of time for a radiation-induced cancer to get going. I'm very aware that I should not skip recommended screening colonoscopies, for example. (I just had my first colonoscopy and it was fine. No cancer, no polyps, no sign of radiation damage.) Surgery has a long, well-known history of success, but as you know by now, some sexual side effects are likely, and how severe they will be is not possible to predict beforehand. However, if your surgeon can spare the nerve bundles, your youth will be an advantage in regaining erections. You may also have some problems with continence (holding your urine) and it's likely you will have to wear some kind of pads for a short time after surgery. How long and how severe the urinary problem will be is also impossible to predict ahead of time. I think most men are dry within a matter of weeks or months, but some have long term problems. **You need to find the best prostate surgeon you can if you choose surgery** Freezing is called cryotherapy. My father had it 20 or so years ago and it apparently cured his cancer. His PSA never came back. It fell out of favor for a while, due to extreme sexual side effects, but I think it's regained some popularity and techniques have probably gotten better. Radiation is not free from side effects. A lot of guys get a gradual erectile problem in the years after radiation. Sometimes you can have urinary side effects. The main advantage to radiation, in my book, is that it's a very easy treatment to tolerate. The treatments themselves are painless and non-invasive (if you have external radiation). You could also have seeds (brachytherapy) or a combination of external radiation and brachytherapy. I should add that I had some bowel problems after radiation--called radiation proctitis. But they got better and vanished within a matter of weeks. Some guys have longer term bowel issues after external radiation. Don't let the side effects scare you away from treating your cancer. You can't have erections or go to the bathroom in a coffin, after all. Try to focus on getting rid of the cancer by finding a treatment that is in line with your preferences and values, and find the best doctor you can who performs that treatment. Do not automatically go with doctors you already know. You have one big chance. Take your time and think things out. I highly recommend Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer (3rd edition). Best wishes. Originally Posted by OTCHU Hello everybody. Posts.Title: biopsy result yesterday ... I have prostate cancer at 40 years old. Need advices

Posts.Content: PPicard, You should brace yourself for a dance with the bear. When PSA is slightly elevated, this could be something benign, but when PSA is 20 or above, that goes out the window. When PSA is over 20, the odds of PCa are at least 90%. http://prostatecanceruk.org/informat...blems/psa-test A study by the University of Florida found that when PSA was 30 or higher, the probability of cancer is 100%: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17722667 and in fact when it's over 30, it is probably no longer organ-confined. http://www.prostate.org.au/testing-f...ate-cancer.php When PSA is over 100, it's extremely likely the patient already has metastases in the bone. http://omicsonline.org/1948-5956/JCST-03-112.php http://www.ijnm.in/article.asp?issn=...=Kamaleshwaran You should have a biopsy to confirm and find out the aggressiveness (Gleason score) and stage. Biopsies are nothing to be terrified of anymore, in terms of pain. Your urologist should give you a local anesthetic, and if you want, a mild sedative like Valium to take the edge off. I wouldn't be surprised if your doctor will want to start you on hormone therapy immediately, even before you get test results. You have stated that you don't want to fight this if the cost is high in terms of quality of life. My reaction is that you need to fight this just to preserve your QOL. Hormone therapy is well tolerated by a lot of men. It usually stalls prostate cancer for a period of months to a few years, and in some cases, decades. After that there are other treatments. I think that untreated, death from prostate cancer would be slow and very painful. In contrast, with treatment you may be able to enjoy a normal lifespan with side effects that you can easily live with. (A friend of my father's went in with a painful leg--turns out he had metastatic prostate cancer. He went on HT and for the next 8 years, lived a very normal life, enjoying his family and hobbies. He eventually succumbed, but his quality of life in the intervening years was very good) I'm not trying to diagnose you--I surely hope you *don't* have prostate cancer. Find out what's going on (biopsy) and I hope you let us know and stay active in this forum. There is a lot of help available here and elsewhere. Best wishes,

Posts.Title: Just got a PSA reading of 300

Posts.Content: Hi again. Yes, that's correct. My prostate was removed. Apparently, and hopefully, the reason my PSA came back was that a little cancerous tissue was left behind in the area where the prostate was. That can happen. It's not like removing a very well-defined body part. The reason my doctors and I think that some cancer was left behind in the area of the prostate was that radiation to that area was so effective in reducing my PSA to undetectable. If you have surgery, you will get a report on your surgical margins. "Negative" means that there was no cancer at the edges of the removed tissue. "Positive" means there was cancer right up to the edge (and presumably, OVER the edge and still inside you!) So you want negative margins after surgery. My margins were positive, meaning it was likely some cancer remained behind, and the salvage radiation pretty much confirmed that. If the cancer had been somewhere else (like my bones) the radiation would not have had the same effect. How long do you have? I'm no doctor, of course, but I don't think taking a couple of weeks to let the panic fade and educate yourself will hurt. The cancer has been developing over a very long time frame, and a couple of weeks to relax, learn, and evaluate your options can only help. You are not in imminent danger and there's no need to rush, but there's no reason to put off setting up some consultations. Just my opinion. Originally Posted by OTCHU thank you for reply ... I am very new to this so maybe my question will be stupid, so sorry about that. You said that you had a surgery, so that mean that they took out your prostate, right ? And you said that your PSA did come back .. that's mean the cancer was somewhere else ? I am confuse about that My PSA was at 2.86 ... the meds was doing nothing so they decided to do a biopsy and here we are Again I am very lost right now .. I really dont know what to do .... how long time I have before to take a decision, what decision to take ... I am so glad to have this forum ... thanks again

Posts.Title: biopsy result yesterday ... I have prostate cancer at 40 years old. Need advices

Posts.Content: PPicard, You should brace yourself for a dance with the bear. When PSA is slightly elevated, this could be something benign, but when PSA is 20 or above, that goes out the window. When PSA is over 20, the odds of PCa are at least 90%. http://prostatecanceruk.org/informat...blems/psa-test A study by the University of Florida found that when PSA was 30 or higher, the probability of cancer is 100%: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17722667 and in fact when it's over 30, it is probably no longer organ-confined. http://www.prostate.org.au/testing-f...ate-cancer.php When PSA is over 100, it's extremely likely the patient already has metastases in the bone. http://omicsonline.org/1948-5956/JCST-03-112.php http://www.ijnm.in/article.asp?issn=...=Kamaleshwaran You should have a biopsy to confirm and find out the aggressiveness (Gleason score) and stage. Biopsies are nothing to be terrified of anymore, in terms of pain. Your urologist should give you a local anesthetic, and if you want, a mild sedative like Valium to take the edge off. I wouldn't be surprised if your doctor will want to start you on hormone therapy immediately, even before you get test results. You have stated that you don't want to fight this if the cost is high in terms of quality of life. My reaction is that you need to fight this just to preserve your QOL. Hormone therapy is well tolerated by a lot of men. It usually stalls prostate cancer for a period of months to a few years, and in some cases, decades. After that there are other treatments. I think that untreated, death from prostate cancer would be slow and very painful. In contrast, with treatment you may be able to enjoy a normal lifespan with side effects that you can easily live with. (A friend of my father's went in with a painful leg--turns out he had metastatic prostate cancer. He went on HT and for the next 8 years, lived a very normal life, enjoying his family and hobbies. He eventually succumbed, but his quality of life in the intervening years was very good) I'm not trying to diagnose you--I surely hope you *don't* have prostate cancer. Find out what's going on (biopsy) and I hope you let us know and stay active in this forum. There is a lot of help available here and elsewhere. Best wishes,

Posts.Title: Just got a PSA reading of 300

Posts.Content: My understanding is that in about 90% of men after prostatectomy, sperm travel to the bladder. This is called retrograde ejaculation and is not dangerous. I would see a urologist about any tenderness in the testicles. There are multiple things it could be, (inguinal hernia or epididymitis, for example, which are fairly common after prostatectomy and no big deal to fix). Good luck.

Posts.Content: I agree with the others. Don't panic. See a urologist, who will order a PSA and DRE. If you can get them done sooner, all the better, because you could get treated to see if antibiotics help. If the PSA and DRE are abnormal, then you would get a biopsy. There's no reason to think it's cancer. The culprit is more likely prostatitis (in my non-professional opinion). But get completely checked out. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Feeling Terrible

Posts.Content: Leroy, I'm sorry to hear about your troubles. In advanced prostate cancer, hormone therapy, (technically ADT, or androgen deprivation therapy), often does help. How long it helps varies widely from man to man, but it's common for it to help for a few years. However, I am aware of a man who says he has been on hormone treatment for over a decade. He was diagnosed after the cancer had already spread to the rectum wall. Such a long period of benefit from hormone therapy is probably the exception. I'm going to tell you what Walsh says in his book under the heading "How Long Do Hormones Work?", on p. 468: "This varies from man to man, and we expect these numbers to change with the explosion of new strategies for attacking hormone-resistant cancer. Ten percent of men who are started on HT when they have metastases to bone live less than six months. Ten percent live longer than 10 years. The other 80 percent fall somewhere in the middle. Statistics have shown that half of these men live three years or fewer, and 25 percent are alive after five years." At some point, PSA rises, because the cancer cells that were resistant to the treatment gradually come to dominate the tumors. That's called becoming hormone refractory. After that point, there is still help from medicine in the form of chemotherapy. New treatments are in development. Your best strategy will be to delay and stall the cancer as long as possible while those treatments are being developed and tested. Don't give up hope--work is progressing on several fronts in this battle. You should be seeing a medical oncologist if you have not already. Radiation might be needed as well, to zap spots in your bones where you're having pain, and you would have to see a radiation oncologist for that. This would not be curative, of course, but it can often relieve pain. I wish you well. I hope you have friends and family you can call upon for support. Don't fight this alone. I'm sure people will support you on this discussion board. If you have not yet done so, I suggest finding the nearest "US TOO" support group in your area if you are in the United States. Info can be found on http://www.ustoo.org Good luck!

Posts.Title: Stage D metastatic prostate cancer survival rate

Posts.Content: I agree with az4peaks. Also, radiation techniques have improved dramatically since the early days. You recall that your dad had radiation and had to wear both a urinary catheter and a colostomy bag. That would be pretty much unheard of today. Radiation is not risk-free, and at least one member of this forum has serious side effects but generally, salvage radiation isn't too hard on a person. In a lot of cases, like mine, any side effects are mild and temporary. As Bravehardon indicated, the technology is much better at limiting collateral damage. That said, it's not something to be undertaken lightly. Hopefully, your PSA will stabilize at a low level and you won't need secondary treatment. But if you do, it's nothing to be terrified of (in my opinion). I didn't even miss work. Take care, and take courage--your numbers still look pretty darn good.

Posts.Content: I read about prostate cancer treatments in the news all the time, but then again I like to read major newspapers and I have a Google news alert set up from prostate cancer. How about Zytiga? Zytiga doubled the PSA doubling time of men on it, compared to men just getting prednisone, and the trial was halted so that more men could get the drug. SF Chronicle: http://www.sfgate.com/health/article...ed-3603973.php Other PCa drugs beating placebos (bearing in mind that a successful trial doesn't mean the drug is anywhere close to a silver bullet, and may only provide a modest survival time increase): MDV3100: http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/757883 Xtandi (already mentioned) Cometriq (Cabozantinib): http://www.oncologynurseadvisor.com/...rticle/274313/ Jevtana http://www.centerwatch.com/drug-info...px?DrugID=1103 Interesting article here: http://online.wsj.com/article/SB1000...964538152.html

Posts.Title: Challenge  name a successful prostrate drug

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DebbieMH Last week we went to the urologist and he did an exam, found nothing - then said just for giggles, do a PSA test. My husband did and it came back at 177. He went in for a bone scan Friday. The urologist said that he has advanced prostate cancer. That he didn't need to do a biopsy because his PSA was so high. The bone scan hasn't come back yet. He has no symptoms ... and is only 61 years old. Is that true ... a PSA that high actually means cancer, period? First of all, I'm sorry to hear about that PSA. It does not bode well. I'm curious--was this his first-ever PSA test? Did he also have a DRE (rectal exam)? If so, what was that result? As far as I know, as a layperson, only a biopsy can definitively diagnose prostate cancer. That said, when PSA is over 10, the probability of cancer is 67%, according to research by Alan Partin and others. When it's over 20, the odds increase to 90%, and many will be metastatic with mets visible on bone scans. When PSA is over 100, the patient almost certainly has prostate cancer and it is very likely metastatic. I don't know enough to discuss whether or not your husband should have a biopsy---what utility that would provide vs. the risk in his situation. It would tell you the Gleason score, an indication of the aggressiveness of the cancer. With advanced prostate cancer, the specialist to see is a medical oncologist, preferably one who specializes in prostate cancer. There are treatments available which potentially can stop cancer in its tracks, reduce metastasis, and maximize quality of life. They are, however, thought of as palliative and not curative. I would ask for a re-test to confirm the PSA results. I hope this helps. I'm sorry you've been dealt this challenge.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DebbieMH No, he is seeing a urologist. I'm thinking if the bone scan comes back bad, then get the urologist to refer him to MD Anderson CAncer in Houston. Any thoughts on that? I would say if you have access to MD Anderson in Houston, go there. By all means. They are ranked #1 in the US by US News & World Report for cancer treatment. They're also highly rated for urology--so for a urologic cancer like prostate cancer, that's a great combination. They are one of three original comprehensive cancer centers established with federal assistance in 1971. They are one of 66 National Cancer Institute-recognized Centers of Excellence, and have conducted more clinical trials than any other cancer research organization. Get a referral to a top notch medical oncologist there, and your husband will be in excellent hands. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Husband PSA 177

Posts.Content: I know what you mean, Fairwind, and it could be seen as jumping the gun to go to HT without a biopsy first. I would bet that a doctor at M.D. Anderson would want to to a biopsy. That said, the statistics show that it is virtually certain that he has cancer, if the lab test was not a huge error. What's less certain is whether it's metastatic yet or maybe just locally advanced. What I've read indicates that prostatitis can cause spikes in PSA five to seven times "normal". So if "normal" is (let's be generous) 4, then you'd be looking at at readings of 20 to 28. Not 177. And I can't imagine you could have normal prostate tissue producing any where close to 177 in a case of BPH. I've read about the same thing--readings can be as high as 25 or 30 from BPH, but not much higher. "False-positive elevations in the PSA are increases in the PSA that are caused by conditions other than prostate cancer. For example, benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and infection or inflammation of the prostate (prostatitis) from whatever cause can elevate the PSA. Note also that even a rectal examination or an ejaculation within the prior 48 hours can sometimes elevate the PSA. False-positive elevations are usually in the 4 to10 range, but they can go as high as 25 or 30." http://www.medicinenet.com/prostate_cancer/page5.htm PSA over 20 carries with it a 90% risk of cancer, and this gentleman is nearly 8 times that.

They are one of 66 National Cancer Institute-recognized Centers of Excellence, and have conducted more clinical trials than any other cancer research organization. Get a referral to a top notch medical oncologist there, and your husband will be in excellent hands. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DebbieMH Last week we went to the urologist and he did an exam, found nothing - then said just for giggles, do a PSA test. My husband did and it came back at 177. He went in for a bone scan Friday. The urologist said that he has advanced prostate cancer. That he didn't need to do a biopsy because his PSA was so high. The bone scan hasn't come back yet. He has no symptoms ... and is only 61 years old. Is that true ... a PSA that high actually means cancer, period? First of all, I'm sorry to hear about that PSA. It does not bode well. I'm curious--was this his first-ever PSA test? Did he also have a DRE (rectal exam)? If so, what was that result? As far as I know, as a layperson, only a biopsy can definitively diagnose prostate cancer. That said, when PSA is over 10, the probability of cancer is 67%, according to research by Alan Partin and others. When it's over 20, the odds increase to 90%, and many will be metastatic with mets visible on bone scans. When PSA is over 100, the patient almost certainly has prostate cancer and it is very likely metastatic. I don't know enough to discuss whether or not your husband should have a biopsy---what utility that would provide vs. the risk in his situation. It would tell you the Gleason score, an indication of the aggressiveness of the cancer. With advanced prostate cancer, the specialist to see is a medical oncologist, preferably one who specializes in prostate cancer. There are treatments available which potentially can stop cancer in its tracks, reduce metastasis, and maximize quality of life. They are, however, thought of as palliative and not curative. I would ask for a re-test to confirm the PSA results. I hope this helps. I'm sorry you've been dealt this challenge.

Posts.Content: I know what you mean, Fairwind, and it could be seen as jumping the gun to go to HT without a biopsy first. I would bet that a doctor at M.D. Anderson would want to to a biopsy. That said, the statistics show that it is virtually certain that he has cancer, if the lab test was not a huge error. What's less certain is whether it's metastatic yet or maybe just locally advanced. What I've read indicates that prostatitis can cause spikes in PSA five to seven times "normal". So if "normal" is (let's be generous) 4, then you'd be looking at at readings of 20 to 28. Not 177. And I can't imagine you could have normal prostate tissue producing any where close to 177 in a case of BPH. I've read about the same thing--readings can be as high as 25 or 30 from BPH, but not much higher. "False-positive elevations in the PSA are increases in the PSA that are caused by conditions other than prostate cancer. For example, benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and infection or inflammation of the prostate (prostatitis) from whatever cause can elevate the PSA. Note also that even a rectal examination or an ejaculation within the prior 48 hours can sometimes elevate the PSA. False-positive elevations are usually in the 4 to10 range, but they can go as high as 25 or 30." http://www.medicinenet.com/prostate_cancer/page5.htm PSA over 20 carries with it a 90% risk of cancer, and this gentleman is nearly 8 times that.

Posts.Content: Jim, I don't have experience or knowledge about such situations, and your predicament sounds a little unusual. Hopefully your doctor is a top-notch medical oncologist. If not, I would consult one. Best wishes for your health. Originally Posted by jbdubose I was diagnosed with prostate cancer and had prostatectomy in Dec. 09'. I had a high cancer score (8+). The follow-up PSA test a few weeks after showed my level at 2.9. The doctor was astounded saying the margins were clear from my surgery. So he did another PSA a week later and it was 3.2. Evidently he did not get it all and it was climbing up fast. So, in Mar. 10' I got sent to radiation for 40+ treatments and as an added "bonus" I got started on Lupron. Yes, I have now read all the bad stuff on the drug and completely agree with many assessments. It did a number on me as well. I was on the drug for 1.5 years getting zeros all the while and talked my doc into getting off of it (Nov. 11'). He said it would take the same amount of time for the drug to wear off before my PSA tests would be truly accurate and for my hormone levels to bounce back. But he did mention that I was not a candidate for HRT since I was stage 3 at one point (Radiation, etc). Since Nov. 11' I have continued to get zeros on my PSA but my pituitary gland never kicked back and my hormone levels ranged 68 until recently. Now they are dropping (50) again. Now, the doc has ordered some pituitary blood tests to see if a tumor is present. He has also relented and has put me on HRT (via gel). Options? Is there any medicine, natural or otherwise, out there that can "jumpstart" my pituitary? Although there may be a risk in doing HRT again, I have done extensive research and have found that prognosis unstable. So I am 50/50 on HRT. Has anyone in this forum experienced this or have heard of this happening? Any advice? Please help...I am pretty frustrated! Thanks in advance, Jim

Posts.Content: Gary, I'm sorry to hear that. You've been dealt a bad hand of cards, haven't you? Try a google search for this: mucinous adenocarcinoma prostate Take care with the spelling of the first two words for the best results. It would seem to be rare indeed. I found this article from the Archives of Pathology and Laboratory Medicine, 2005 (see the link for the full citation). The title is "A Rare Prostatic Tumor in a 48-Year-Old Man". It would seem from the article that there have been about 60 cases reported. The article notes that although the outlook is dismal, there HAVE been cases of long term survivors. http://tinyurl.com/5ab284 Another article indicates that mucinous adenocarcinoma is not any worse than other prostate cancers. The authors conducted what they believe to be the largest study of this rare cancer (14 cases) and concluded: "MC appears to behave clinically in a similar fashion to AC, with no statistically significant difference in biochemical failure or survival." (By AC they mean "regular" prostate cancer, or conventional adenocarcinoma.) http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retri...90429506006212 It would seem that you are in mostly uncharted waters here. I suggest in addition to reading what literature that is available and consulting with the best cancer experts you can get to, that you contact a very knowledgeable layperson. His name is John and his email--which he publishes openly on WebMD--is [email protected] Good luck, Gary. My thoughts are with you.

Posts.Content: What are possible side effects? As others wrote, the most likely side effects would be some loose bowel movements, possibly diarrhea and painful bowel movements. He might have some increased urgency of urination. Not everyone gets these side effects, and most of the time, when men do, they're tolerable, treatable and temporary. It's possible he could have some increased erectile difficulties. The increased ED, if it happens, is a gradual phenomenon. Where could it have spread to? Not possible to say with existing scans where it might be, unless it's far enough along for mets to show up (very unlikely at his current PSA level) but hopefully it's still in the area where the prostate was, which is called the prostate bed, or fossa. If so, radiation offers a second chance at a cure. You didn't say whether he had positive surgical margins or not--if he did have pos margins, the odds are more favorable towards localized, curable cancer. If his lymph nodes or seminal vesicles were involved, the odds are not so favorable. The Gleason 9 does indicate an aggressive tumor and that is not good. There is a calculator on the Memorial Sloan Kettering website that can help you determine his odds of success, but you will need more information from his medical record, including pre-op PSA history, and the post-op pathology and staging. ***He may be angry that maybe the surgeon left something behind, but if this IS the cause of his rising PSA, it's good news, because radiation can mop it up*** Will he be able to drive to treatments or will it tire him out? I can only speak for myself. I was able to drive to treatments, just taking a half hour out of my work day. I didn't experience any fatigue. However, I was only 43. I know that some men report significant fatigue, but I think they would still be able to drive. What is life expectancy post radiology? You probably mean in terms of prostate cancer, not overall (since statistically, he is nearing the edge of male life expectancy anyway for the US). If the radiation is successful, he won't be bothered by prostate cancer ever again. If not, I don't think it's possible to say, but he would probably need to go on hormone therapy. And if that was as effective as it usually is, the cancer would be stalled for many months to several years, possibly allowing him to live out a normal lifespan not very bothered by the cancer itself. Can he be around his grand children during 7 weeks of radiology? Yes. It's not like brachytherapy. The patient is not radioactive at all. The most common treatment is IMRT, which uses X-Rays. The beams come in from various directions, controlled by computer. Each beam is weak, but they combine in the target area to cumulatively reach a therapeutic level. The treatments are painless, and they are not frightening or intimidating. Boring, mostly. You lay still for a few minutes, the machine makes some noise and moves a few times, and then you go back to your day. What did you find useful being done for you by your family. For me it was quite an easy thing to go through. If surgery was a "10" on the stress level, my salvage radiation was about a 1 or 2. So I didn't feel like I needed any kind of special attention from my family, other than understanding that I was anxious to see whether it worked. (And it did) You may find this article helpful: "9 Decisions Before Electing Radiation Therapy After Radical Prostatectomy" http://prostate-cancer.org/PDFs/Is13-2_p8-17.pdf and this one with good news about side effects: "Few Side Effects Found From Radiation Treatment Given After Prostate Cancer Surgery" http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases...928131212.htm# Originally Posted by squiggle Hi advice wanted My dad's cancer has recurred any my family naturally are devastated. Though I knew it would happen as his level was considered to be gleason 7 (4+3) stage 2c pre surgery but was revised to gleason 9 (5+4) on examination of operative samples. It was considered to be very aggresive at the time. Post operatively he had levels of 0,01 doubling to 0.02, and continuing to double until 18month post op level was 0,18 He has been referred to radiology, he is 70 and scared and angry as he feels that it wasnt all removed. What can I do to help him? He is worried that it has spread and where it has gone along with the side effects of radiology 5 days per week for 7 weeks testing in Jan start Feb. What are possible side effects? Where could it have spread to? Will he be able to drive to treatments or will it tire him out? What is life expectancy post radiology? Can he be around his grand children during 7 weeks of radiology? What did you find useful being done for you by your family. Any advice/ suggestions or bare fact reality welcomed. I was a nurse years ago but never in this area so all advice/experience welcome. Plain spoken truth welcome as I need to know facts as I am his go to for advice and I need to be ready. I am trawling relevent sites on internet for advice Thanks in advance for any advice offered

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DebbieMH Last week we went to the urologist and he did an exam, found nothing - then said just for giggles, do a PSA test. My husband did and it came back at 177. He went in for a bone scan Friday. The urologist said that he has advanced prostate cancer. That he didn't need to do a biopsy because his PSA was so high. The bone scan hasn't come back yet. He has no symptoms ... and is only 61 years old. Is that true ... a PSA that high actually means cancer, period? First of all, I'm sorry to hear about that PSA. It does not bode well. I'm curious--was this his first-ever PSA test? Did he also have a DRE (rectal exam)? If so, what was that result? As far as I know, as a layperson, only a biopsy can definitively diagnose prostate cancer. That said, when PSA is over 10, the probability of cancer is 67%, according to research by Alan Partin and others. When it's over 20, the odds increase to 90%, and many will be metastatic with mets visible on bone scans. When PSA is over 100, the patient almost certainly has prostate cancer and it is very likely metastatic. I don't know enough to discuss whether or not your husband should have a biopsy---what utility that would provide vs. the risk in his situation. It would tell you the Gleason score, an indication of the aggressiveness of the cancer. With advanced prostate cancer, the specialist to see is a medical oncologist, preferably one who specializes in prostate cancer. There are treatments available which potentially can stop cancer in its tracks, reduce metastasis, and maximize quality of life. They are, however, thought of as palliative and not curative. I would ask for a re-test to confirm the PSA results. I hope this helps. I'm sorry you've been dealt this challenge.

Originally Posted by Hawk Hello to all, I have been pretty scarce here. Had surgery at MSKCC in 2004 for Gleason 8 - followed by salvage radiation 2009. My PSA dropped to a low of .02 by 2011. It started back up in 2014 (0.06) and as of Dec 2015 it is at .25 with a doubling time of about 10 - 12 months. I am looking for the earliest possible imaging such as C11 Acetate PET. and also possible consultation on risk/ befits of early treatment. I suspect at this point my best shot would be that I gained access to C11 Acetate PET, that a small hot-spot was found and radiated and BINGO ! Any one know of access to C11 Acetate PET within reasonable access to the east coast. Anyone ever hear of treatment at these low PSA levels? Thanks Hawk

Posts.Content: My first biopsy was unpleasant bordering on painful. No anesthetic other than lidocaine gel on the probe. The next one was awful. Again, no anesthetic and all I could do to not jump off the table. And that was with a couple of doses of Valium under my belt. Time for the third one, couple of years later. My uro assured me that now he gave an injection of lidocaine, and that it would be much better. But from the look on my face, he knew I might jump ship. He offered to do it in the hospital, under general anesthetic. He did, and it was a piece of cake, and it was positive for cancer, so at least I knew I was done with biopsies. The hospital version set me back a few hundred bucks, but it was worth every penny. A friend of the family got a raging infection after a prostate biopsy (I never had any post-biopsy complications). All said, a biopsy found my cancer, at long last, and I doubt anything else would have in time to save me. I don't think I would have undergone treatment without the proof. I do sympathize with guys who have a bad experience.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PCWIFE3 Hello: back again with another question. My husband had Davinci surgery 3 weeks ago today. He had his catheter removed last Friday. While he had the catheter, there was ALWAYS blood in his urine. The doctor took a look and said that this was likely due to the catheter rubbing against the bladder and should go away within a few days of removing it. Since he had the catheter removed, he's had no problems with incontinence (thus far), but every time he urinates, he has a spasm and then a drop of fresh blood comes out. He said he has a really strong stream and just before he is done, it automatically stops with a sharp spasm and new blood. I called the nurses and they said that this could be normal and to follow up with his doctor. We don't see him until the 16th of November so just wondering if anyone else has had a similar issue? Again thanks to all of you who post here....you've really put my mind at ease about so much. I agree that it's a normal consequence of healing. I had the spasms, and got something (forgot now what it was) to reduce them. The doctor should be able to call in the Rx without seeing your husband ahead of schedule.

Posts.Title: Spasms after catheter removal

Posts.Content: I agree with Newporter. Especially in the case of radiation, therapies are more effective and patients suffer fewer side effects than 20 years ago. I would much rather be diagnosed with prostate cancer in 2013 as opposed to 1993. IMRT, in particular, was a revolution in radiation therapy. It did not become widely available until about 10 years ago. I had IMRT as a salvage treatment after surgery failed to cure me. Proton beam therapy has also become available in the last 20 years. If you go back a little further, things have improved even more. Walsh introduced the nerve sparing prostatectomy in 1982, and I'm sure it took a few years for that technique to be widely disseminated. Before then, the nerve bundles were always removed with the prostate, leaving the man impotent. Now there's a good chance for the surgeon to preserve the bundles. And like newporter wrote, there is now chemo available for advanced cases. Although it's not curative, in many cases it extends survival time. In the 1980's I don't think there were any effective chemo therapies for prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: Have they made improvements

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Zentea Almost 4 years ago i had a radical prostatectomy. My gleason score had been6 or 7. the psa was 13.5 at its highest. Three months after surgery my first psa was.2. Long story short, it stayed that way for 3.5 years. This spring it went to .4. I had radiation and the first psa came back at .2. Seems im back where i started. After talking to my surgen and my oncologist i'm confused about what they said exactly and what this means. No one told me what to expect after the radiation. I assumed it would go to zero, more than likely, because my cancer had been contained and was in less than1% of the prostate. How Could it still even be there. Well, asked and ansewed with all the possibilities. On line i got some info, but nothing with numbers this low to start radiation. Not sure where i stand or whats next except more psas's and wait and see. Our cases aren't very different. What we had is often called "salvage radiation". The first PSA after salvage radiation is completed often isn't zero. Yours wasn't, mine wasn't. (Mine was 0.1). What's more important is what happens next. It does take a little time for the cancer cells that were irradiated to die off--in the meantime, they still produce PSA. If your salvage radiation was successful, your PSA should fall to "less than 0.1" on the standard test and stay there. The best outcomes are when this low point is reached within a year of the date you finished radiation. So 90 days after radiation my PSA was still detectable, at 0.1. But 90 days after that, it was less than 0.1, where it has stayed (I'm now 5 1/2 years out from the end of radiation). So don't sweat this first test result. Hopefully you'll trend downwards now and be effectively at zero before long--and cured. Hopefully we both are.

Posts.Title: post radiation result

Posts.Content: Has he been diagnosed with prostate cancer? If not, I echo Chuck's question: has a biopsy been done, or is it scheduled? If he was diagnosed, what was his Gleason score? Although BPH and prostatitis (both benign) can raise PSA, you would not expect to see it at 300 or more and not be cancer. I've seen on numerous medical sites that when PSA reaches 100, it's almost certainly cancer and it has very likely escaped the prostate. For example: "...for PSA levels more than 100 ng/ml, all subjects in our study had proven to have skeletal metastases on radionuclide bone scan. The positive predictive value using a cut off point of a serum PSA more than 100 ng/ml is 100%" http://www.omicsonline.org/1948-5956/JCST-03-112.php I think it's safe to assume that he has PCa and that it is advanced. It's good that it's not showing up in his bones yet. Is he receiving treatment? Hormone therapy is effective in many men, at least for a matter of months or years (sometimes decades) and then there are other treatments.

Posts.Content: Hawk, I'm not very active here anymore, but I remember you and often wondered how you were doing. As you probably recall, I have a personal and rather selfish interest in SRT outcomes. Your self-assessment seems spot-on to me. If you want, you can email me directly at [email protected] (mod--I'm aware of and okay with the consequences of posting an email address here) Have you thought about a C11 PET scan before proceeding with treatment? http://gucasym.org/utility-c-11-chol...static-disease . There is a trial underway, in Phase 2, "Non-systemic Treatment for Patients With Low-volume Metastatic Prostate Cancer", NCT01558427. Apparently the availability of C11 scans is quite limited, but one of the locations is my metro area, so I have it in the back of my mind, should my PSA start to climb (it has not, as of January, approximately 7 years post-SRT). I wish you the best. Originally Posted by Hawk As you can see from my profile signature I had surgery, and got some low PSA readings after 46 months. I opted for high dose salvage radiation while my PSA was still around .15 Ultimately my PSA dropped to .02 although that took a while. I went some time without a psa test (approx 1 year) In Feb 2014 it was up to .06 Six months later in July of 2014 it is .10 All and all the SRT took my Gleason 8 PCa down to undetectable limits for 5 years. It seems pretty clear to me that I have a tiny amount of localized Gleason 8 cancer that I will have to deal with so now I begin the process of educating myself with the many varied opinions on when to start HT etc. Comments and opinions are welcome.

Posts.Content: I had a prostatectomy in 2006. Gleason 3+4, positive margins. My PSA started to rise several months later, and in 2007 I had salvage radiotherapy (SRT), in the form of IMRT at my local hospital. When I started radiation my PSA was 0.7 and the doubling time was under 90 days. I had my PSA checked last week, and it remains less than 0.1. I don't have any lingering side effects from radiation, and a recent colonoscopy came out good--no cancer, no polyps, no obvious sign of radiation damage.

Posts.Content: Mayo Clinic has an FDA-approved Choline C-11 PET scan that aims to do just that--determine where the recurrence is coming from. http://www.mayoclinic.org/tests-proc...n/prc-20021137 "Choline C-11 PET scan is an imaging test used to help detect sites of prostate cancer that have returned despite treatment (recurrent prostate cancer)." My layperson's take on these scans is that they are a big step forward in identifying micrometasases in some patients, but they're not perfect. I think if my PSA goes up now (8 years post-SRT) I'd try the scan and see if anything would show up that could be targeted with radiation, instead of going straight to hormone therapy, as had been my original plan. +

Posts.Title: PSA rise after SRT are there tests to track down where the rising PSA is "lurking"

Posts.Content: As Fairwind wrote, it does take time--assuming the radiation is successful at eradicating the remaining cancer--for PSA to fall. I had surgery, then radiation when my PSA rose. The day before I started radiation, my PSA was 0.7. I was not tested until 3 months elapsed after the radiation treatments. At that point, my PSA was still detectable on the standard test, at 0.1. My doctor said he would have been pleased even if had been higher, say 0.3. At the next test, at the 6 month post-radiation mark, my PSA was less than 0.1. It has remained there since. Maybe I'm cured, maybe I'm just enjoying a long term remission. Maybe a piece of plaque in my arteries will slough off as I reach for the morning paper tomorrow and drop me in the driveway! It hasn't been long since your radiation ended. The tumor cells that were irradiated should die now, without replicating, since the radiation damages their DNA, making replication impossible. As they die off, your PSA should come down. With luck, it should come down to less than 0.1, and for the best outlook, that should happen in less than 12 months from the end of radiation. So wait, and see what the next test brings. As Fairwind wrote, in the medium term, the odds are about 50/50. In the very short term, most men do see their PSA go down (about 3/4). Within a few years, about half of them will have a PSA recurrence. At the 10 year mark, that rises to 75%. (However, men who see a total response to radiation tend to be better off, with 1/3 of them making it to the decade mark without recurrence.) My blog has links to studies backing the above stats. But in the end, you're a man, not a number, as the 60's tv show "The Prisoner" used to say. You've rolled the salvage radiation dice, and now the only thing to do is wait for them to come to rest and see what the results are. If it's any encouragement, I've followed the stories of quite a few guys here, and on HealingWell.com, who have had salvage radiation. There have been a few failures, but there are more successes, at least a few years out. Best wishes!

Posts.Content: I had EBRT (in the broad sense of the term, meaning external). It was IMRT at my local hospital, done as salvage after a prostatectomy failed to cure me. I had 70.2 grays over 38 sessions. I had some minor bowel issues that resolved soon after treatments ended. Otherwise, no side effects. And it seems to have wiped out the remaining cancer, as my PSA remains undetectable years later. I would find out what "flavor" of EBRT your place does. If you're not comfortable with it, travel to have your radiation done. I almost went out of state to have proton beam therapy, but opted to stay close to home for logistical reasons.

Posts.Title: IS EBRT radiation outdated

Posts.Content: There's a similar scan in clinical trial, the C-11 Acetate PET/CT. This article about the acetate scan notes the problem with the C-11 choline scan being relatively insensitive where PSA is under 2.0. "In the PSA greater than 2ng/mL range, AC shows a 90% detection rate compared to 86% for choline. In the lower PSA range (0.4 to 2.0ng/mL), AC has a much higher overall detection rate of 77% compared with 60% for choline." http://www.urotoday.com/uij-current-...carcinoma.html More information about this scan is here: http://www.azmolecular.com/prostate-imaging The trial is currently only available in Phoenix, AZ. The NCI information sheet on the trial is here: http://www.cancer.gov/clinicaltrials...archid=6553437 The trial is in phase II. Phase II trials normally recruit a few dozen participants (Phase III trials go for hundreds or thousands of patients). Phase II is to further evaluate safety and to begin evaluating how effective the procedure is. Fingers crossed that this one will work out as it promises.

Posts.Title: PSA rise after SRT are there tests to track down where the rising PSA is "lurking"

Posts.Content: Carmen, If radiation is given to your husband, it will probably be in the hope that any cancer cells are still in the area where the prostate used to be, called the prostate bed, or fossa. There is no way to guarantee the cells are there. The CT and bone scans only rule out obvious mets, but can't detect microscopic cancer. The scans do *not* have to find a target for the radiation. Usually the cancer would be too tiny to show up, anyway. The radiation would be aimed at the prostate bed. The highest dose would be given to where the doctor thinks the cancer is most likely to be, and lower doses in outer areas. The radiation can be shaped to try to avoid hurting healthy tissue and organs. Radiation given this way is often called salvage radiation therapy, or SRT for short. It's what I (and a few others here) have had. It is a painless treatment that takes a few minutes a day, 5 days a week, for about 2 months. There would be no guarantees that it would work, but the sooner your husband started the treatments, the better his chances. However, if the cancer has escaped the pelvic region, the SRT will not do anything to help him. In the very short run--months to a couple of years out from SRT, most men, about 75%, see their PSA decrease. At the 5 year mark, the number of men who have not had a rise drops to around 50% (this is the 50/50 you read about). By 10 years, the overall odds drop to around 25%, although in men who saw their PSA go all the way down to less than 0.1, the odds are a little better---about 35%. So it's a gamble. It always is. The upside to the gamble is a second chance at a cure. The downside to the gamble is that it might not work at all, and your husband could suffer in terms of his quality of life. *Usually* the side effects from salvage radiation are mild, and go away within a few months. But not always. There is a chance your husband could suffer from long term irritation to his rectum or bladder. He could even be injured by the radiation if there is a mistake, but this is not common. Radiation also increases a man's chance of a different cancer years later. For me the second chance of a cure was enough. I wish the best for you and your husband.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by theszak What do abbreviations CT, GH, MH, UA reference?... in GH: CT and Cytology were normal. No GH in 6 years, no MH since 2003. Will forego cystoscopy unless new GH or MH on UA. CT = computed tomography ("cat" scan) UA = urinanalyis GH = gross hematuria (blood visible in urine to naked eye) MH = microscopic hematuria (blood visible microscopically) When you Google for MH and GH and cystoscopy, you get some journal abstracts about urological issues that use them. Like this one: "GROSS hematuria (GH) or microscopic hematuria (MH) may be a clue to serious urologic disease, including malignancy." http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article....ticleid=381751

Posts.Title: Factors that determine prognosis for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: I agree. Get the biopsy. The trend is not your friend. If it's positive for cancer, you won't need to think about free PSA, but if it's negative, you'll probably want to get that for the reason Tat2 stated. Catalona and other influential doctors say that a rise of more 0.4 or more in one year is reason to suspect cancer. BPH (benign enlargement) can cause PSA to rise, but much more gradually than that. Prostatitis, on the other hand, causes much larger and sudden spikes (3.0 or greater rise in one year). So you don't fall into either category according to that thinking. Your PSA velocity is apparently too fast for BPH to be the cause, too slow for prostatitis. Of course, there aren't many certainties in prostate cancer. The biopsy will provide useful information, either way. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: New Poster

Posts.Content: Tim, it's hard to predict. I had surgery at 43. I have some ED from the surgery, but can recover to 100% with a pill. Some guys come out better, some worse. I know you will find this difficult to believe, but the side effect that would be more devastating to your quality of life is incontinence. Luckily, I'm okay in that regard too, 99.9% dry. If you have surgery, your risk of impotence will depend on the skill of the surgeon--you need absolutely the best you can find--and whether or not they are able to spare one or both nerve bundles. At your age, if the surgeon can leave the nerves, you'll probably recover enough sexual function that it won't be a big deal. Your youth will also help with the risk of incontinence. With a Gleason 6, you have multiple options--seeds, external radiation, surgery, proton beam, and so forth. There's no need to rush to a decision. I recommend getting the latest edition of Patrick Walsh's "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer". And take some time to read up on all of your options. If you choose surgery, you should not automatically go with your urologist, but rather pick the best doctor you can from a center of excellence near you (in the states, that would be places like UCLA, Memorial Sloan Kettering, MD Anderson, Dana Farber, Johns Hopkins, etc.) If you get a great surgeon, at a great hospital, at age 43 the odds are you'll have a pretty normal sex life afterwards AND not be wetting your pants every time you sneeze. If you go with a mediocre surgeon at a community hospital...well, it's anyone's guess. Surgery has some things going for it. It seems to have a slight statistical edge in long term cancer-free survival for younger (<50) patients. The pathologist gets to look at the removed tissue and tell you what's really going on. And there's a psychological boost many men get from knowing "it's out." But impotence and incontinence (the second, especially) need to be carefully considered. You don't have to have surgery. Radiation is comparable (according to surgeon Walsh) to surgery in cancer control overall, the part about young men notwithstanding. The risk of incontinence from radiation is almost nil, although the opposite risk--developing a stricture that blocks urine--is more present in radiation than surgery. You can still have sexual dysfunction after radiation, but it tends to be more gradual when it occurs. The biggest advantage to radiation is that it ain't surgery. I was pretty miserable for the first few days after surgery. Hated the catheter. I later had radiation, and found that to be a cakewalk in comparison. (However, my radiation was salvage in nature, not a primary treatment, so I may not be painting an accurate picture). Don't panic, don't rush. Get Walsh's book, visit the Prostate Cancer Research Foundation website http://www.pcf.org and click on "Newly Diagnosed". Relax, read widely, think things through, sketch out the pros and cons of the various treatments in terms of your priorities. This is your big chance to get this right. You're young, you can beat this, and come out the same person on the other side. Wishing you well--

Posts.Title: 44yrs old with prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Tim, it's hard to predict. I had surgery at 43. I have some ED from the surgery, but can recover to 100% with a pill. Some guys come out better, some worse. I know you will find this difficult to believe, but the side effect that would be more devastating to your quality of life is incontinence. Luckily, I'm okay in that regard too, 99.9% dry. If you have surgery, your risk of impotence will depend on the skill of the surgeon--you need absolutely the best you can find--and whether or not they are able to spare one or both nerve bundles. At your age, if the surgeon can leave the nerves, you'll probably recover enough sexual function that it won't be a big deal. Your youth will also help with the risk of incontinence. With a Gleason 6, you have multiple options--seeds, external radiation, surgery, proton beam, and so forth. There's no need to rush to a decision. I recommend getting the latest edition of Patrick Walsh's "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer". And take some time to read up on all of your options. If you choose surgery, you should not automatically go with your urologist, but rather pick the best doctor you can from a center of excellence near you (in the states, that would be places like UCLA, Memorial Sloan Kettering, MD Anderson, Dana Farber, Johns Hopkins, etc.) If you get a great surgeon, at a great hospital, at age 43 the odds are you'll have a pretty normal sex life afterwards AND not be wetting your pants every time you sneeze. If you go with a mediocre surgeon at a community hospital...well, it's anyone's guess. Surgery has some things going for it. It seems to have a slight statistical edge in long term cancer-free survival for younger (<50) patients. The pathologist gets to look at the removed tissue and tell you what's really going on. And there's a psychological boost many men get from knowing "it's out." But impotence and incontinence (the second, especially) need to be carefully considered. You don't have to have surgery. Radiation is comparable (according to surgeon Walsh) to surgery in cancer control overall, the part about young men notwithstanding. The risk of incontinence from radiation is almost nil, although the opposite risk--developing a stricture that blocks urine--is more present in radiation than surgery. You can still have sexual dysfunction after radiation, but it tends to be more gradual when it occurs. The biggest advantage to radiation is that it ain't surgery. I was pretty miserable for the first few days after surgery. Hated the catheter. I later had radiation, and found that to be a cakewalk in comparison. (However, my radiation was salvage in nature, not a primary treatment, so I may not be painting an accurate picture). Don't panic, don't rush. Get Walsh's book, visit the Prostate Cancer Research Foundation website http://www.pcf.org and click on "Newly Diagnosed". Relax, read widely, think things through, sketch out the pros and cons of the various treatments in terms of your priorities. This is your big chance to get this right. You're young, you can beat this, and come out the same person on the other side. Wishing you well--

Posts.Title: 44yrs old with prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Hi-- When you write about the two options, you fail to mention salvage radiation. It is mentioned on the Phoenix5 website, and in the JAMA article "Risk of Prostate CancerSpecific Mortality Following Biochemical Recurrence After Radical Prostatectomy". (Assuming that's the article to which you refer). In the JAMA article, men who had complete responses to salvage radiation were considered--for the purpose of the study--cured and were then excluded from the study. So the two choices of wait or start ADT come AFTER the participants had the chance to try radiation. Somewhere around 50% of men will get at least a durable response of several years--and may potentially be cured--by salvage radiotherapy after having PSA rise after prostatectomy. These days the side effects, though still present, are much milder with the advent of IMRT, image-guided IMRT, and protons. Dr. Andrew Stephenson is a lead researcher in this field. He recently, along with these estimable co-authors: Scardino, Kattan, Slawin, and Pollak, et al., did a very large study of 1,600+ patients from 1985 to 2005. They did a multivariate study of all the factors that might affect the success of salvage therapy. The article, "Predicting the Outcome of Salvage Radiation Therapy for Recurrent Prostate Cancer After Radical Prostatectomy" (Journal of Clinical Oncology, May 2007), provides a nomogram for patients and doctors faced with a rising PSA after prostatectomy. I had salvage IMRT done, and as I was considering it, became acquainted with a patient at Loma Linda UMC having proton beam salvage. He had negative margins, I had positive. Both of us had short (3 mos. or so) PSA doubling times. Both of us have seen our PSAs fall back to undetectable levels after radiation. I'm quite relieved that I was able--at age 44--to have a second chance. I wasn't ready to sit back and wait for metastasis or go on ADT. On my blog at http://pcabefore50.blogspot.com , I chronicle what it's like to be young and have prostate cancer, and what IMRT salvage was like. I also summarize and link to research on predicting the outcome of salvage. Thanks for running a great board---I mean this to be informative and not an attack.
