Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Hammer2016 Hello all, I had my RALP in July 2016. I've had 3 post surgery PSA tests done. They were as follows; 8/26 .04psa 9/23 .06psa 11/17 .12psa I am already working with a radiation oncologist and will be receiving salvage radiation. He has gone over many of the possible side effects, but it's hard to know which, if any, of them I will experience. I do hope someone out there can put me at ease. I was speaking with another patient at the doctor today who said his radiation therapy burned and was painful during the procedure. I hope that is a rare issue. Any comments will be appreciated. Thanks! Hammer I had salvage radiation (IMRT, Varian machine) in 2007. There was absolutely no sensation other than a little boredom during the treatments. 38 sessions. Towards the end of the treatments, say, with about 2 weeks to go, I started to have some discomfort during bowel movements. It was radiation proctitis. No huge deal--I got a prescription for something called Proctofoam that cooled things down, and within a few weeks after SRT, the discomfort was gone. I did not experience fatigue, and didn't miss any work. In fact, the week after I finished, we took a family trip to Disneyland and I was full steam ahead. Best of all, the treatment worked.

Posts.Content: Even men who suffer devastating side effects from prostatecomies can have sex. Half the world's population has sex, and orgasms, without a single erection or even a penis. Orgasms happen mainly in the brain. So I wouldn't fret that you run the risk of "never having sex again" but it's rational to worry about whether or not you will have erections. Again, at 44 with relatively low risk cancer--if you find the right surgeon, you'll probably be able to function normally again (except there won't be semen any more) and you might have to use a medication or other ED treatment to be completely like you were before.

A yeast infection is a fungus infection, but if you try the creams made specifically for vaginal yeast infections, you might have better success than if you used ones that are more generically designed. Cheap and easy. Beyond that, I'd see a doctor. Look for Clotrimazole.

Posts.Content: I used the Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center calculator and got 17.5 months. I was guessing at exact dates, but that shouldn't make a big difference. I used 1 Sept 2013, 15 Dec 2013, 15 Jan 2014, 15 Feb 2014, 30 March 2014. However, if I used just the last two readings, I get a doubling time of 4 months. Probably what the oncologist is doing. PSA doubling time is not straightforward because the kinetics come out to a curve, not a straight line. The formula is td = (ln 2 x t) / {ln [PSAt]  ln [PSAinitial]} which is a pain, so it's easier to use an online calculator. Of course I'm not a doctor, but I have read articles by specialists that say you need multiple data points to accurately gauge doubling time---two is not enough. So I would go with the results obtained from 5 data points, which yields a more reassuring figure.

Posts.Content: I had a quick recurrence (at 9 months) after surgery and rapid doubling time (less than 3 months) and positive margins. I also had the same Gleason as your husband, and like your husband, fairly young (44 in my case at the time) I did not have hormone therapy. It was not really a choice laid out to me. I just had the radiation. The advantage to NOT having HT with SRT is that you get a clearer picture sooner afterwards. If I had had HT along with it, I would have suspected HT was masking the effect of radiation for some time afterwards. On the other hand, there are studies that show HT along with radiation is better than just radiation. Early recurrence and rapid doubling does not always indicate distant metastases, and your husband's positive margins provide a local explanation for the PSA rise. Hopefully, those margins indicate some tumor was left behind at the prostate bed and now radiation can mop it up. I'm doing fine several years out now. Here's to your husband having a similar outcome. R. Originally Posted by Iamthewife Hi everyone, My H was diagnosed at age 50 with prostate cancer in April 2014. Don't recall his exact numbers, but he went from ~3.6 to ~5.3 at his next check. Had Davinci RP in late May 2014, PSA after was undetectible. Pathology report indicates G7 (3+4), 3 positive margins, grade T2c. PSA rechecks every 3 months. His cancer recurred in less than a year. PSA of .06, a retest two weeks later was .07, and 3 months later it's .15. That means his doubling time is less than 3 months. He started salvage radiation last week. His oncologist said he was on the fence about hormone therapy with the radiation, so my H has opted for no hormones. Wanting to know if others have had early recurrence and rapid doubling time. Did your doctor tell you hormone treatment was 50/50? I've read that early recurrence and PSADT <3 months could indicate distant mestastices, and that hormone therapy with radiation could knock out both. Thoughts on where he is in treatment and the advice he's been given?

Posts.Title: Early recurrence, rapid doubling time - questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Iamthewife As I've said before here, my H doesn't want to talk about his cancer, at least not the important things. I asked him if he is having his PSA checked during radiation and he said he's not. He then went on to tell me that you don't start hormone therapy during radiation, only before. I hadn't mentioned hormones, so I know he was being defensive and wanting to shut me down. Here's my concern - I don't think his doctors are being honest with him. His cancer has recurred in less than 1 year and his psadt is less than 3 months. Based on this chart from Johns Hopkins, he can't be cured. His chances of surviving 15 years are about 1%. How can they suggest to him that radiation could cure him in this case? http://urology.jhu.edu/newsletter/pr..._cancer829.php The way I read the chart, he has a 74% chance of prostate cancer-specific survival at 5 years. Not so great longer out, but that data was based on men being treated back when salvage radiation was much cruder, and it no doubt includes men who didn't even try radiation after surgery. I would encourage you to look at a nomogram which has been validated and re-validated, predicting the outcome of salvage radiation. https://www.mskcc.org/nomograms/pros...iation-therapy I put in some numbers (not knowing all the details of your husband's pathology) and it looks like he should be around the 44% probability of being free of PSA progression 6 years later--that was about where my probability was. (I assumed negative lymph and seminal vesicle invasion--if he had either one of those it will downgrade his odds a little). If you can get your hands on his records, you can get a clearer picture, but it's far from doomsday. A lot of cancer patients would give their left...arm for a 40% chance of a cure. Again, I was in almost exactly the same position: rapidly doubling PSA, positive margins, Gleason 7, no hormone therapy, etc. and things have worked out very well for me. There is good reason for the two of you to be optimistic. One last thought: a study by Trock in 2008 showed that men with rapidly doubling PSA have the most to gain from salvage radiation: "Feb. 12, 2008 -- For the first time, researchers have shown that radiation can increase the odds of survival for men whose PSA levels rapidly rise after surgery for prostate cancer...[t]he greatest benefits of so-called salvage radiotherapy were observed in men with rapidly rising PSA levels, says researcher Bruce Trock, MD, associate professor of urology, epidemiology, oncology, and environmental health sciences at Johns Hopkins University." http://www.webmd.com/prostate-cancer...-for-radiation

Posts.Title: Early recurrence, rapid doubling time - questions

Posts.Content: Walsh, on p. 164 of "Dr. Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer", says: "If you have a low PSA level (between 1 and 4 ng/ml), any increase is alarming. In a study using data from the Baltimore Longitudinal Study of Aging, Carter and colleagues found that PSA increases greater than 0.2-0.4 ng/ml per year were predictors of death from prostate cancer. Currently, change in PSA over time is the most valuable tool we have for interpreting PSA and for predicting prostate cancer, including whether it is life threatening." In my LAYPERSON'S opinion, you should be seeing the urologist about this. I wouldn't put a lot of confidence in what the family doctor says. I bet the urologist will want to see another PSA much sooner than 12 months from now.

Posts.Title: Question on PSA rise of .3 ng/ml in 1 year

Posts.Content: The individual lab company should have that information. I got a nice email in reply to my voicemail to a chief chemist with a local lab. My concern at the time, as I recall, was a PSA of 0.2 after prostatectomy. That was my second test result after surgery, the first being less than 0.1. After prostatectomy, PSA should fall below 0.1 and stay there. In the email response, the chemist told me that the lab experienced variation of up to 0.1 ng/mL between machines. That is, if the same sample were tested on two different pieces of equipment, it might be different by as much as 0.1 ng/mL. Well, that wasn't extremely comforting, because it meant that I was still probably no lower than 0.1, and maybe as high as 0.3. At the time I was trying to assess my odds of progressing further, and I had some studies at hand that showed the odds, depending on your present PSA. Being 0.2 or 0.3 was not a good sign. The chemist suggested getting an ultrasensitive PSA assay done for greater accuracy. My doctors aren't fans of ultrasensitive testing, and I don't really want the anxiety that goes along with watching numbers bounce around from 0.03 to .05 and so forth, so I haven't pressed for it. Walsh (p. 380) says that Daniel Chan of Johns Hopkins "trusts the sensitivity of assays down to 0.1 ng/mL, or slightly less than that." I assume he's talking about the standard (non-ultrasensitive) test. That sounds in line with what the lab person told me. John is right--you really need to look at a trend of PSA over time. bb is asking about PSA in the pre-treatment stage. Since he has a prostate, PSA can be affected by several things. Variation in the lab is certainly a possibility, and so is inflammation, infection, prostate stimulation through DRE or sex, etc. bb asked about doubling time...PSA doubling time is calculated by dividing the natural log of 2 by the slope of the relation between the log of PSA and the time of PSA measurement. (whew--thank goodness for computers!) PSADT calculators do this using all of the available dates and measurements. In my uneducated opinion, it would seem like you would need quite a few measurements over many months to accurately graph the curve. But that's just my amateur's view. IMHO, in the post-surgical setting, PSA is a more useful tool than it is before surgery takes place. If my PSA goes up, I know it's not because of prostatitis, BPH, sex, or exam. There's nothing left there to irritate. (I know the surgeon didn't leave a glob of prostate behind because of high resolution CT scans and the old "finger wave" exam). It would almost certainly be because of cancer, once lab variation was ruled out by subsequent or repeat tests.

Salvage radiation (IMRT) total dose 70.2 Gy, Jan-Mar [email protected] age 44 PSA 6/07 0.1, 9/07 (and thereafter) <0.1 http://pcabefore50.blogspot.com
Posts.Title: Question on PSA rise of .3 ng/ml in 1 year

Posts.Content: Jim, the way I would look at is to generally accept the PSA score for what it is, but realize it might be off 0.1 in either direction (on the standard test.) In my own case, if my next PSA is 0.1 instead of less than 0.1, I'll be worried, but I'll tell myself that it's possible that it's just normal lab variation. That variation within a lab might be different from lab to lab; I don't know.

Posts.Title: Question on PSA rise of .3 ng/ml in 1 year

Posts.Content: The individual lab company should have that information. I got a nice email in reply to my voicemail to a chief chemist with a local lab. My concern at the time, as I recall, was a PSA of 0.2 after prostatectomy. That was my second test result after surgery, the first being less than 0.1. After prostatectomy, PSA should fall below 0.1 and stay there. In the email response, the chemist told me that the lab experienced variation of up to 0.1 ng/mL between machines. That is, if the same sample were tested on two different pieces of equipment, it might be different by as much as 0.1 ng/mL. Well, that wasn't extremely comforting, because it meant that I was still probably no lower than 0.1, and maybe as high as 0.3. At the time I was trying to assess my odds of progressing further, and I had some studies at hand that showed the odds, depending on your present PSA. Being 0.2 or 0.3 was not a good sign. The chemist suggested getting an ultrasensitive PSA assay done for greater accuracy. My doctors aren't fans of ultrasensitive testing, and I don't really want the anxiety that goes along with watching numbers bounce around from 0.03 to .05 and so forth, so I haven't pressed for it. Walsh (p. 380) says that Daniel Chan of Johns Hopkins "trusts the sensitivity of assays down to 0.1 ng/mL, or slightly less than that." I assume he's talking about the standard (non-ultrasensitive) test. That sounds in line with what the lab person told me. John is right--you really need to look at a trend of PSA over time. bb is asking about PSA in the pre-treatment stage. Since he has a prostate, PSA can be affected by several things. Variation in the lab is certainly a possibility, and so is inflammation, infection, prostate stimulation through DRE or sex, etc. bb asked about doubling time...PSA doubling time is calculated by dividing the natural log of 2 by the slope of the relation between the log of PSA and the time of PSA measurement. (whew--thank goodness for computers!) PSADT calculators do this using all of the available dates and measurements. In my uneducated opinion, it would seem like you would need quite a few measurements over many months to accurately graph the curve. But that's just my amateur's view. IMHO, in the post-surgical setting, PSA is a more useful tool than it is before surgery takes place. If my PSA goes up, I know it's not because of prostatitis, BPH, sex, or exam. There's nothing left there to irritate. (I know the surgeon didn't leave a glob of prostate behind because of high resolution CT scans and the old "finger wave" exam). It would almost certainly be because of cancer, once lab variation was ruled out by subsequent or repeat tests.

Posts.Content: Walsh, on p. 164 of "Dr. Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer", says: "If you have a low PSA level (between 1 and 4 ng/ml), any increase is alarming. In a study using data from the Baltimore Longitudinal Study of Aging, Carter and colleagues found that PSA increases greater than 0.2-0.4 ng/ml per year were predictors of death from prostate cancer. Currently, change in PSA over time is the most valuable tool we have for interpreting PSA and for predicting prostate cancer, including whether it is life threatening." In my LAYPERSON'S opinion, you should be seeing the urologist about this. I wouldn't put a lot of confidence in what the family doctor says. I bet the urologist will want to see another PSA much sooner than 12 months from now.

Posts.Title: Question on PSA rise of .3 ng/ml in 1 year

Posts.Content: Fairwind is right. No need to panic over 0.1, but stay vigilant. If you show consecutive rises, you will have to consider salvage radiation (SRT for short). The hard part will be the waiting. Most doctors would not initiate SRT at 0.1, until there is a pattern. The reason is that there is a subset of men who rise to 0.1, but no further. To radiate those men would unnecessarily subject them to possible side effects. In the long run, salvage radiation appears to cure, or at least give a durable response, to 25-30% of patients. That's the long run. In the shorter run (3 years) it seems to be effective about half the time. In the short run, it causes PSA to fall to undetectable levels in about 3/4 of men. So the farther you look out, the more dismal it gets, but it's still something. Lots of cancer patients would jump for a 1 in 3 second chance at a cure. Usually, the only way to know if it's going to work is to try it. Imaging is not helpful, usually, with PSA at that low level. There is a nomogram on the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center website that can help you estimate your odds of success with SRT, but it's only a rough estimate, and you have to keep in mind that it is most accurate for large statistical groups and is not a crystal ball for an individual. You will need your medical record to complete the nomogram. If you and your doctor decide on SRT, you won't know for sure if it's going to help. The good news is that for most men, the side effects of SRT--if you experience any--are likely to be mild and transitory. Some men do experience increased sexual dysfunction, some don't. A lot of us get some mild bowel/rectal problems that go away. For a few men, side effects are worse, and a tiny percentage of men are injured by radiation. The downside of the gamble is pretty limited, and the upside is tremendous--a second chance at a cure. If you visit HealingWell.com's prostate cancer forum, there are several guys who were successfully treated with SRT, and a few that were not helped. There was a recent thread about SRT here: http://www.healingwell.com/community...f=35&m=2583429 In my case, SRT seems to have worked. My PSA quickly fell to undetectable after treatment, and has stayed there since. I have no side effects at this point that I can tie to the radiation treatments. My ED did not get worse after SRT and in fact has improved over the past few years. I get tested again this month. It's been 6 years since I started SRT, nearly 7 years since my diagnosis. My full story is in my blog at http://pcabefore50.blogspot.com . You might also find this article about a Mayo clinic study interesting: http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases...0928131212.htm I wish you well and hope you keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Gimmy, the controversy about PSA screening does not extend to RetiredGuy's case. He is being tested, not screened, and even PSA screening critics like Ablin say that PSA is useful in the post-treatment setting. Here is Ablin in the NYT op-ed piece you cited: "Prostate-specific antigen testing does have a place. After treatment for prostate cancer, for instance, a rapidly rising score indicates a return of the disease. And men with a family history of prostate cancer should probably get tested regularly. If their score starts skyrocketing, it could mean cancer." http://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/10/opinion/10Ablin.html Originally Posted by Gimmy Retired guy, in a march 11, 2010 op- ed piece in the new York times written by ricard ablin the inventor of the psa test , he calls the psa " a profit driven public health disaster" and recommends not doing psa test because it cannot detect prostate cancer,etc.....the American medical association recommended no more testing on may 25, 2012.... The AAFP and the uspstf also recommended not doing psa test on may 22, 2012.... Hope this info helps you. Having already been through all this ,I wish i'd never heard of the psa test......I hope you stop taking the test, don' t even think about it you'll almost for sure going to die of something else many years down the road...enjoy your retirement .... God Bless...Gimmy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Iamthewife As I've said before here, my H doesn't want to talk about his cancer, at least not the important things. I asked him if he is having his PSA checked during radiation and he said he's not. He then went on to tell me that you don't start hormone therapy during radiation, only before. I hadn't mentioned hormones, so I know he was being defensive and wanting to shut me down. Here's my concern - I don't think his doctors are being honest with him. His cancer has recurred in less than 1 year and his psadt is less than 3 months. Based on this chart from Johns Hopkins, he can't be cured. His chances of surviving 15 years are about 1%. How can they suggest to him that radiation could cure him in this case? http://urology.jhu.edu/newsletter/pr..._cancer829.php The way I read the chart, he has a 74% chance of prostate cancer-specific survival at 5 years. Not so great longer out, but that data was based on men being treated back when salvage radiation was much cruder, and it no doubt includes men who didn't even try radiation after surgery. I would encourage you to look at a nomogram which has been validated and re-validated, predicting the outcome of salvage radiation. https://www.mskcc.org/nomograms/pros...iation-therapy I put in some numbers (not knowing all the details of your husband's pathology) and it looks like he should be around the 44% probability of being free of PSA progression 6 years later--that was about where my probability was. (I assumed negative lymph and seminal vesicle invasion--if he had either one of those it will downgrade his odds a little). If you can get your hands on his records, you can get a clearer picture, but it's far from doomsday. A lot of cancer patients would give their left...arm for a 40% chance of a cure. Again, I was in almost exactly the same position: rapidly doubling PSA, positive margins, Gleason 7, no hormone therapy, etc. and things have worked out very well for me. There is good reason for the two of you to be optimistic. One last thought: a study by Trock in 2008 showed that men with rapidly doubling PSA have the most to gain from salvage radiation: "Feb. 12, 2008 -- For the first time, researchers have shown that radiation can increase the odds of survival for men whose PSA levels rapidly rise after surgery for prostate cancer...[t]he greatest benefits of so-called salvage radiotherapy were observed in men with rapidly rising PSA levels, says researcher Bruce Trock, MD, associate professor of urology, epidemiology, oncology, and environmental health sciences at Johns Hopkins University." http://www.webmd.com/prostate-cancer...-for-radiation

Posts.Content: It is my understanding that MDV3100 blocks the action of testosterone, which would naturally cause erectile dysfunction and lack of libido (sexual drive). But if your dad is looking at MDV3100 (now Xtandi) isn't he already on/has been on hormone therapy? Dr. Scholz, a major medical oncologist specializing in prostate cancer, addresses this question here: http://prostatesnatchers.blogspot.co...1_archive.html and the answer would seem to be that it's unclear what "extra" sexual side effects Xtandi brings to the table, since trial participants were already on Lupron, which suppresses sexual function. I'm just an outside observer in the world of advanced prostate cancer. You might want to ask this question on HealingWell.com, where you are more likely to find MDV3100 (Xtandi) users who can give you a better "inside picture". Or have your dad ask his oncologist. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Kazzie61, welcome to the forum. I agree with lancepeace. Don't panic. There is no imminent threat of losing your husband. The 5 year survival rate overall is near 100%, and it's also very good for 10 years when caught early enough. When you get the biopsy results you'll be armed with information to make a decision about treatment. Hopefully it's localized to the prostate--MRI notwithstanding--and this will be just a bump in the road for him, like it is for many men. Keep calm & carry on!

Posts.Content: Good post, Putt, and my condolences on the loss of your wife. Personally, I don't think of myself as being cured, but edging closer to it every year, like an asymtote--a curve that continues to move closer to a line without ever touching. As time goes by I think I'm possibly cured, and after a number of years I'll say I'm probably cured. But remission is still a better word. I don't know if I'll ever state flatly that I'm cured. I don't think my doctors ever used the word. My dad was treated decades ago, and his PSA never rose above 0.1 afterwards. He's in his early 80's now and facing other health issues. I feel like he's cured--or at the very least, as good as cured, since it's so unlikely that prostate cancer will ever again bother him. (He had cryo, by the way). He has been vigilant all the way.

Posts.Title: Good 6 month followup

Posts.Content: Having positive seminal vesicles adds about 12 points to the total score, putting the odds of progression free status at 50-60% as I read the nomogram. (I wish they'd computerize it as promised at nomograms.org, but it hasn't appeared yet). A lot of cancer patients would jump through hoops for a 50% chance of a cure--and it sounds like your dad has made an informed decision to go for it. I wish him well. He has everything to gain, and not much to lose, from trying salvage radiation. Today's radiation techniques are much more precise than just a few years ago. IMRT, which I had, is a big leap over 3D conformal, which was a huge leap over the crude blocks used before. And now there's IGRT which goes a step further in precision. As you probably know, there is no sensation (except for boredom) during the treatment itself. If side effects appear, it probably won't be for a couple of weeks at least. In my case, I had some rectal irritation that really didn't get too annoying until the very end of treatment. My doctor prescribed Proctofoam, which worked wonderfully at relieving the symptoms, and in the year or so that has passed, the bowel symptoms have largely gone away on their own. Compared to surgery it was a piece of cake. Good luck to your dad.

Posts.Title: Looking for link

Posts.Content: Don't panic. Your doctor is suggesting that you may be a candidate for salvage radiation. That's a second chance at a cure. I think getting re-tested is fine. If your PSA shows any further rise, I would move forward with consultations in regards to radiation. If your PSA holds steady, it probably won't hurt to wait. You would want to get started before your PSA hits 1.0, as research shows men who start before 1.0 do better than those who are on the other side of the mark. Whether or not salvage radiation does indeed cure someone of PCa depends on whether or not the cancer is still localized to the area where the prostate was. If it is still localized, chances of a durable response to radiation are excellent. If it is not localized, but systemic, radiation won't cure. Overall, the odds of success are generally thought of as 50/50. But if you have your complete history at hand, you can use the salvage nomogram at nomograms.org to get a better idea of the odds. I had a prostatectomy in 2006, and my PSA started rising soon afterward. I had radiation last year. In my case, I was ready to go for salvage radiation even if my chances were 1 in 10, maybe lower. My odds were better, but far from a sure bet. It seems to have worked. Only time, lots of time, will tell. You needn't fear the treatments themselves. They are completely painless, devoid of any sensation except perhaps boredom for a few minutes each day. Side effects are possible, but for most men they are mild and temporary. My blog at http://pcabefore50.blogspot.com details my experiences with salvage radiation, and links to research I found useful. There are others on this board, besides me, who have found themselves in your situation. Sometimes I go to Catholic Mass with my wife, in spite of my agnosticism. I find something the priest says at the end reassuring. I'm not sure if it's part of the standard "script" followed by priests, but in his benediction, he asks for freedom from undue anxiety. That is what I wish for you. Freedom from undue anxiety. Hope. There's plenty of reason to be hopeful. We would all like to be done with the fight after surgery, but some of us find that we have to climb back in the ring for another round. The good news is, lots of us WIN the 2nd round! Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Factors that determine prognosis for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: I see that I do have enough info for the flow chart. * Pre-RT PSA less than 2.0 (assumed) * Gleason 4-7 * negative margins (I assume this is what you mean by no margins--this is a critical piece of information. Negative margins means there was no cancer at the cut edge of the tissue removed). * No node or vesicle invasion * Doubling time less than 10 months ( it came out to .69 years, or 8.28 months, calculated on http://kevin.phys.unm.edu/psa/6formg.html ) Going through the flow chart, the odds of salvage radiation resulting in progression-free status 4 years out is 48%. If the margins were POSITIVE, on the other hand, the 4 year outlook is 57% chance of being progression free. The reason is that positive margins provide a logical explanation for a local recurrence (cancer left behind in the prostate bed). A caution: I don't have the exact dates of the PSA tests. I ran the PSADT by putting in each score 3 months after the previous, starting with a random date. The issues of margins caused me CONSIDERABLE angst in my own personal case, because the uro told me I had negative margins, and even wrote that on the cover sheet he sent to the radiation oncologist. But when the oncologist read the actual surgical report, he found that I had positive margins, which increased my odds of success. Keep in mind that statistics are just statistics, and that all these studies are backward looking by necessity. The patients involved were sometimes undergoing radiation at lower doses than is delivered safely today, with equipment that is outmoded by today's standards--so these studies are most likely overly pessimistic.

Posts.Title: to beam or not to beam

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by johnT As Replicant pointed out seminal vessicle involvement and a rapid doubling time in PSA are both indicative of a systemic disease rather than a local reoccurrance, all making SRT less effective. Three consecutive rises in psa after SRT is an indication of failure. At this point I would be consulting with a medical oncologist that specializes in Prostate cancer for his recommendations. There are late studies that show that by adding a short course (6 months of HT) along with radiation added a significant benefit to G7 patients. I agree with JohnT. The PSA is almost certainly coming from prostate cancer, and it's likely that the cancer is systemic. It would not be thought of as curable at this point, but hopefully manageable for a long time with hormone therapy. I also agree that your father should be in the care of a medical oncologist who specializes in prostate cancer. That will optimize his chances for keeping the cancer at bay. The strategy now shifts from defeating the cancer to stalling it. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: It seems like you DO have a high baseline BUT you are so far above normal now for your age, as Skippy wrote, that it looks ominous, especially when you consider the trend over time and the fact that Cipro only slightly affected it. Perhaps this is caused by a benign condition such as BPH or prostatitis. But maybe you have prostate cancer. I'm surprised you haven't been re-biopsied at this point. A "free PSA" test, which measures to the ratio of free to total PSA, could also shed some light on things. Like Skippy says, I would not mess around with this. If you don't have access to a top-notch (world class) urologist, you should travel to one, and get to the bottom of this. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: I took 3 weeks off (as I remember) probably a little more than I needed for my desk job. I could have gone back as soon as the catheter was out. My catheter stayed in a full two weeks. I started to recover rapidly at home, even with the catheter, and started puttering around (against medical advice, I suppose, at times). Cooking a little, pruning some bushes, even drove myself to a restaurant one day. The incisions weren't much of an issue, neither was pain. The catheter was just a major annoyance the last several days. I was pretty young at the time (43) which was probably in my favor, and I didn't have any complications. I would try to follow the doctor's advice, and take a few unpaid days if necessary. Maybe your husband will heal rapidly and the doctor will update the advice. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Recovery from DaVinci Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: The individual lab company should have that information. I got a nice email in reply to my voicemail to a chief chemist with a local lab. My concern at the time, as I recall, was a PSA of 0.2 after prostatectomy. That was my second test result after surgery, the first being less than 0.1. After prostatectomy, PSA should fall below 0.1 and stay there. In the email response, the chemist told me that the lab experienced variation of up to 0.1 ng/mL between machines. That is, if the same sample were tested on two different pieces of equipment, it might be different by as much as 0.1 ng/mL. Well, that wasn't extremely comforting, because it meant that I was still probably no lower than 0.1, and maybe as high as 0.3. At the time I was trying to assess my odds of progressing further, and I had some studies at hand that showed the odds, depending on your present PSA. Being 0.2 or 0.3 was not a good sign. The chemist suggested getting an ultrasensitive PSA assay done for greater accuracy. My doctors aren't fans of ultrasensitive testing, and I don't really want the anxiety that goes along with watching numbers bounce around from 0.03 to .05 and so forth, so I haven't pressed for it. Walsh (p. 380) says that Daniel Chan of Johns Hopkins "trusts the sensitivity of assays down to 0.1 ng/mL, or slightly less than that." I assume he's talking about the standard (non-ultrasensitive) test. That sounds in line with what the lab person told me. John is right--you really need to look at a trend of PSA over time. bb is asking about PSA in the pre-treatment stage. Since he has a prostate, PSA can be affected by several things. Variation in the lab is certainly a possibility, and so is inflammation, infection, prostate stimulation through DRE or sex, etc. bb asked about doubling time...PSA doubling time is calculated by dividing the natural log of 2 by the slope of the relation between the log of PSA and the time of PSA measurement. (whew--thank goodness for computers!) PSADT calculators do this using all of the available dates and measurements. In my uneducated opinion, it would seem like you would need quite a few measurements over many months to accurately graph the curve. But that's just my amateur's view. IMHO, in the post-surgical setting, PSA is a more useful tool than it is before surgery takes place. If my PSA goes up, I know it's not because of prostatitis, BPH, sex, or exam. There's nothing left there to irritate. (I know the surgeon didn't leave a glob of prostate behind because of high resolution CT scans and the old "finger wave" exam). It would almost certainly be because of cancer, once lab variation was ruled out by subsequent or repeat tests.

Posts.Content: Jim, the way I would look at is to generally accept the PSA score for what it is, but realize it might be off 0.1 in either direction (on the standard test.) In my own case, if my next PSA is 0.1 instead of less than 0.1, I'll be worried, but I'll tell myself that it's possible that it's just normal lab variation. That variation within a lab might be different from lab to lab; I don't know.

Posts.Content: Walsh, on p. 164 of "Dr. Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer", says: "If you have a low PSA level (between 1 and 4 ng/ml), any increase is alarming. In a study using data from the Baltimore Longitudinal Study of Aging, Carter and colleagues found that PSA increases greater than 0.2-0.4 ng/ml per year were predictors of death from prostate cancer. Currently, change in PSA over time is the most valuable tool we have for interpreting PSA and for predicting prostate cancer, including whether it is life threatening." In my LAYPERSON'S opinion, you should be seeing the urologist about this. I wouldn't put a lot of confidence in what the family doctor says. I bet the urologist will want to see another PSA much sooner than 12 months from now.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by arabelladuffy Hi, I started a thread earlier in regards to my fathers situation with stage 4 aggressive pc. I don't want to ramble on about it again, so I will try to make this very short. He is at stage 4, mets to his bones, his cancer type is aggressive, he has refused chemo, radiation and surgery. He is receiving hormone therapy, and some type of bone rebuilding stuff, also he is on an alternative medication called Cesium Chloride. He had a CT scan in January... which is when he was diagnosed, and another one last week to see where he is at now. Today, he spoke to his nurse, who informed him that she saw improvement. Is this even possible? I thought hormone therapy slowed things down, not improved? Either way it is good news. Hormone therapy can cause tumors to shrink and PSA to fall. It can even (I think) make tumors disappear from CT scans. Patients often get relief from symptoms and can have their lives extended. But the cancer is still there. So hormone therapy can "improve" things in the sense that it can, at least for a while, beat the cancer back *and* slow the progression. Eventually though, given enough time, the patient becomes hormone refractory, where the cancer doesn't need androgens like it did before. At that point most men would move on to treatments like ketoconozale, taxotere, Provenge, Zytiga, MDV3100, and the other therapies coming along. My guess--only a guess--would be that the improvement reported comes from the hormone therapy, and is similar to what most men experience on HT--a significant palliative effect.

Posts.Title: Is improvement possible???

Posts.Content: I had a quick recurrence (at 9 months) after surgery and rapid doubling time (less than 3 months) and positive margins. I also had the same Gleason as your husband, and like your husband, fairly young (44 in my case at the time) I did not have hormone therapy. It was not really a choice laid out to me. I just had the radiation. The advantage to NOT having HT with SRT is that you get a clearer picture sooner afterwards. If I had had HT along with it, I would have suspected HT was masking the effect of radiation for some time afterwards. On the other hand, there are studies that show HT along with radiation is better than just radiation. Early recurrence and rapid doubling does not always indicate distant metastases, and your husband's positive margins provide a local explanation for the PSA rise. Hopefully, those margins indicate some tumor was left behind at the prostate bed and now radiation can mop it up. I'm doing fine several years out now. Here's to your husband having a similar outcome. R. Originally Posted by Iamthewife Hi everyone, My H was diagnosed at age 50 with prostate cancer in April 2014. Don't recall his exact numbers, but he went from ~3.6 to ~5.3 at his next check. Had Davinci RP in late May 2014, PSA after was undetectible. Pathology report indicates G7 (3+4), 3 positive margins, grade T2c. PSA rechecks every 3 months. His cancer recurred in less than a year. PSA of .06, a retest two weeks later was .07, and 3 months later it's .15. That means his doubling time is less than 3 months. He started salvage radiation last week. His oncologist said he was on the fence about hormone therapy with the radiation, so my H has opted for no hormones. Wanting to know if others have had early recurrence and rapid doubling time. Did your doctor tell you hormone treatment was 50/50? I've read that early recurrence and PSADT <3 months could indicate distant mestastices, and that hormone therapy with radiation could knock out both. Thoughts on where he is in treatment and the advice he's been given?

Posts.Title: Early recurrence, rapid doubling time - questions

Posts.Content: Good post, Putt, and my condolences on the loss of your wife. Personally, I don't think of myself as being cured, but edging closer to it every year, like an asymtote--a curve that continues to move closer to a line without ever touching. As time goes by I think I'm possibly cured, and after a number of years I'll say I'm probably cured. But remission is still a better word. I don't know if I'll ever state flatly that I'm cured. I don't think my doctors ever used the word. My dad was treated decades ago, and his PSA never rose above 0.1 afterwards. He's in his early 80's now and facing other health issues. I feel like he's cured--or at the very least, as good as cured, since it's so unlikely that prostate cancer will ever again bother him. (He had cryo, by the way). He has been vigilant all the way.

Posts.Title: The word "Cured"

Posts.Content: I dreaded the cath removal, and looked forward to it at the same time. It wasn't bad. I would not attempt something like that myself unless it were an emergency, though. Like the others said, there's a balloon with saline keeping the catheter from coming out. In my case, the nurse pushed saline up the cath into my bladder (this is painless, but odd) and when I told her I felt full, she stopped. She did something to empty the balloon, said "ready?" and then swiftly slid it out. I exhaled the whole time, mainly so I'd have something to focus on. It was uncomfortable, but not painful, and it was over in a few seconds, followed by a rush of my bladder contents (she had prepared for this with a pan at my feet). It was glorious to be free of the catheter, and the first urination on my own after the removal was equally glorious.

Posts.Content: How about this: "We present a 64-year-old Caucasian man with no specific urologic or pain symptoms and with an initial PSA serum value of 21,380 ng/ml. Initial laboratory studies showed chronic anemia and elevated alkaline phosphatase, most likely from bone marrow infiltration due to metastatic disease...Treatment was initiated with bilateral subcapsular orchiectomy and bicalutamide therapy in an effort to create total androgen blockade. After 3 months of follow-up, the serum concentration of PSA was 29 ng/ml. CONCLUSION: This case presents an asymptomatic prostate cancer patient with bone and liver metastasis, enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes and the highest PSA level published to date." http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20215802

Posts.Content: I had one right at the large incision from my Da Vinci. It wasn't a huge deal, but when I realized what it was I went to a surgeon and got it fixed. In my case the surgery was quick and easy, and so far it's held up a couple of years. I think they're not all that rare. The surgeon has to cut through the abdominal muscles to get to the prostate, so that leaves a weak spot. Hopefully you're friend is good to go now.

Posts.Content: The six year tool yields more encouraging results. I made some assumptions--you can tell me later if they were correct, but those items where I made assumptions don't have a huge bearing on the result. Prostatectomy PSA 10: 20 points Gleason 7: 20 points Seminal = no: 0 points extracapsular extension = no: 0 points (assumed, but this factor only would add 2 points at the most if the answer was yes) Margins: Negative: 20 points (would be zero for positive margins) persistently elevated PSA = no: 0 points Pre-rad PSA 0.5 (assumed): 15 points PSADT 8 months: 65 points ADT=no: 0 points Radiation dose 70 Gy (assumed--this is what I had and is fairly standard): 10 points Total points: 150 6 year progression free probability (PFP)= 60% Now, bear in mind I made plenty of assumptions, and this nomogram is a ruler and paper affair--you might get a slightly different answer and that is why I would suggest getting the article. The sooner the person starts also affects the total points and the PFP. If, instead of starting at 0.5, he started at 1.0, there would be a net gain of 15 points and the PFP would drop to about 45%. Being progression free 6 years later is not the same thing as being cured, but since most men who fail do so within the first two years, 6 years is a pretty good milestone, I think. Hope that helps!

Posts.Title: to beam or not to beam

Posts.Content: whether tis nobler to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous cancer, or to take up radiation and end them.. Sorry! Just following the theme! The overall odds are actually much better, especially in the short run (5 years). They drop down to something like 25-35% in the long run (look on the web for studies by Catalona and others by Andrew Stephenson, or check out my blog where I have summaries and links). However, for certain groups the odds are much better. There are several important factors. If you have access to a medical library, I suggest getting a copy of "Predicting the Outcome of Salvage Radiation Therapy for Recurrent Prostate Cancer After Radical Prostatectomy" by Andrew Stephenson, Peter Scardino, Michael Kattan, and several other big guns in prostate cancer. It was published in Journal of Clinical Oncology, Vol. 25, Number 15, May 20, 2007, pp. 2035-2041. I can help you obtain a copy if you cannot otherwise do so. Contact me on my blog if you wish. Or, if you provide the following, I will run the numbers through the 4 year flow chart: current PSA, Gleason score from surgery, surgical margins (pos or neg), and at least a rough idea of his PSA doubling time (I can calculate this if you provide his post-surgery PSA scores). And if you have additional information, I can run it through the predicted 6 year progression free probability nomogram. What's needed besides the above items: seminal vesicle invasion (yes or no), lymph node invasion (yes or no), persistently elevated PSA after surgery (yes or no), and whether or not hormone therapy (ADT) was done in conjunction with surgery. I ran my own stats through this as I decided what to do. I have about a 58% chance of being progression free at 6 years. Those are pretty good odds, considering the ease of treatments (couldn't be any easier), and low rate of relatively mild and temporary side effects. This is not the radiation therapy of the past! So I underwent radiation, and it knocked my PSA into the basement. Bottom line: many men can benefit from salvage radiation. I certainly did. Stephenson, the leading researcher in salvage radiation, says "Nearly half of all patients with recurrent prostatectomy have a long-term PSA response to SRT (salvage radiotherapy) when treatment is administered at the earliest sign of recurrence. The nomogram we developed predicts the outcome of SRT and should prove valuable for decision making for patients with a rising PSA level." Sometimes with prostate cancer, there is no rush. But with salvage radiation, time is of the essence (assuming the patient is a candidate). Some men have a considerably better than 50-50 chance. For example, a man with a pre-radiation PSA of less than 2.0, positive margins, and a PSA doubling time of more than 10 months has a 69% chance of being free from PSA progression at 4 years. Optimally, Stephenson says, you want to start before PSA hits 0.5, but if you start before it gets to 1.0 you're still in pretty good shape. A very recent study, just released, is also optimistic about salvage radiation, showing that men who get radiation are about 60% less to die from prostate cancer: http://www.webmd.com/prostate-cancer...-for-radiation Hope that helps--let me know if I can run the numbers for you. When I was getting radiation, I often thought of a Shakespearean line: "Out, damn'd spot! out, I say!One; two: why, then 'tis time to do't." --Shakespeare, Macbeth (Act V, Scene 1)

Posts.Title: to beam or not to beam

Posts.Content: I see that I do have enough info for the flow chart. * Pre-RT PSA less than 2.0 (assumed) * Gleason 4-7 * negative margins (I assume this is what you mean by no margins--this is a critical piece of information. Negative margins means there was no cancer at the cut edge of the tissue removed). * No node or vesicle invasion * Doubling time less than 10 months ( it came out to .69 years, or 8.28 months, calculated on http://kevin.phys.unm.edu/psa/6formg.html ) Going through the flow chart, the odds of salvage radiation resulting in progression-free status 4 years out is 48%. If the margins were POSITIVE, on the other hand, the 4 year outlook is 57% chance of being progression free. The reason is that positive margins provide a logical explanation for a local recurrence (cancer left behind in the prostate bed). A caution: I don't have the exact dates of the PSA tests. I ran the PSADT by putting in each score 3 months after the previous, starting with a random date. The issues of margins caused me CONSIDERABLE angst in my own personal case, because the uro told me I had negative margins, and even wrote that on the cover sheet he sent to the radiation oncologist. But when the oncologist read the actual surgical report, he found that I had positive margins, which increased my odds of success. Keep in mind that statistics are just statistics, and that all these studies are backward looking by necessity. The patients involved were sometimes undergoing radiation at lower doses than is delivered safely today, with equipment that is outmoded by today's standards--so these studies are most likely overly pessimistic.

Posts.Content: Kazzie61, welcome to the forum. I agree with lancepeace. Don't panic. There is no imminent threat of losing your husband. The 5 year survival rate overall is near 100%, and it's also very good for 10 years when caught early enough. When you get the biopsy results you'll be armed with information to make a decision about treatment. Hopefully it's localized to the prostate--MRI notwithstanding--and this will be just a bump in the road for him, like it is for many men. Keep calm & carry on!

Posts.Title: Husband just diagnosed-I'm terrified. Please advise if you can

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by johnT As Replicant pointed out seminal vessicle involvement and a rapid doubling time in PSA are both indicative of a systemic disease rather than a local reoccurrance, all making SRT less effective. Three consecutive rises in psa after SRT is an indication of failure. At this point I would be consulting with a medical oncologist that specializes in Prostate cancer for his recommendations. There are late studies that show that by adding a short course (6 months of HT) along with radiation added a significant benefit to G7 patients. I agree with JohnT. The PSA is almost certainly coming from prostate cancer, and it's likely that the cancer is systemic. It would not be thought of as curable at this point, but hopefully manageable for a long time with hormone therapy. I also agree that your father should be in the care of a medical oncologist who specializes in prostate cancer. That will optimize his chances for keeping the cancer at bay. The strategy now shifts from defeating the cancer to stalling it. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: to beam or not to beam

Posts.Content: Having positive seminal vesicles adds about 12 points to the total score, putting the odds of progression free status at 50-60% as I read the nomogram. (I wish they'd computerize it as promised at nomograms.org, but it hasn't appeared yet). A lot of cancer patients would jump through hoops for a 50% chance of a cure--and it sounds like your dad has made an informed decision to go for it. I wish him well. He has everything to gain, and not much to lose, from trying salvage radiation. Today's radiation techniques are much more precise than just a few years ago. IMRT, which I had, is a big leap over 3D conformal, which was a huge leap over the crude blocks used before. And now there's IGRT which goes a step further in precision. As you probably know, there is no sensation (except for boredom) during the treatment itself. If side effects appear, it probably won't be for a couple of weeks at least. In my case, I had some rectal irritation that really didn't get too annoying until the very end of treatment. My doctor prescribed Proctofoam, which worked wonderfully at relieving the symptoms, and in the year or so that has passed, the bowel symptoms have largely gone away on their own. Compared to surgery it was a piece of cake. Good luck to your dad.

Posts.Content: It seems like you DO have a high baseline BUT you are so far above normal now for your age, as Skippy wrote, that it looks ominous, especially when you consider the trend over time and the fact that Cipro only slightly affected it. Perhaps this is caused by a benign condition such as BPH or prostatitis. But maybe you have prostate cancer. I'm surprised you haven't been re-biopsied at this point. A "free PSA" test, which measures to the ratio of free to total PSA, could also shed some light on things. Like Skippy says, I would not mess around with this. If you don't have access to a top-notch (world class) urologist, you should travel to one, and get to the bottom of this. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: I took 3 weeks off (as I remember) probably a little more than I needed for my desk job. I could have gone back as soon as the catheter was out. My catheter stayed in a full two weeks. I started to recover rapidly at home, even with the catheter, and started puttering around (against medical advice, I suppose, at times). Cooking a little, pruning some bushes, even drove myself to a restaurant one day. The incisions weren't much of an issue, neither was pain. The catheter was just a major annoyance the last several days. I was pretty young at the time (43) which was probably in my favor, and I didn't have any complications. I would try to follow the doctor's advice, and take a few unpaid days if necessary. Maybe your husband will heal rapidly and the doctor will update the advice. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: What Should i Expect

Posts.Content: Similar to what the others wrote, I can tell you that I experienced some bowel irritation (more frequent bowel movements, verging on diarrhea) that became painful. My doctor prescribed over-the-counter treatment for the diarrhea (Loperamide, sold as Imodium in the U.S.), and a topical foam that I applied...well, internally (but itw was easy and totally relieved the pain). Once treatments were over, the bowel issues subsided quickly and I have no problems there now. I didn't have any urinary problems from radiation, nor did it increase the sexual dysfunction I had from surgery. In fact, I've gotten better in that regard over the past few years. I did not notice any fatigue, but then again, I had radiation at a much younger age than most. I think my experience is fairly common, and in line with those of the guys above. Some people do better, some worse, but in general the side effects from external radiation for prostate cancer are mild and temporary. The treatments themselves are very easy, and involve just lying still for a few minutes. No sensation at all other than mild boredom. I agree that what he's gone through from the hormone therapy is probably much worse than anything the radiation will bring on. With kind regards,

Posts.Title: What Should i Expect

Posts.Content: I have a couple of thoughts--first, I don't think I would stick with a non-communicative doctor. You've got a lot riding on this. Second, SRT might be worth a shot. The negative margin status doesn't help your odds of success, but it's just one of several factors. Another crucial factor is your PSA before you start SRT. Statistically, men who start at 0.5 or below do much better. You might want to try the nomogram (a predictive tool) for salvage radiation at the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center: http://nomograms.mskcc.org/Prostate/...onTherapy.aspx You'll want to have your pathology report in hand, and know your PSA history. From your posting, I would guess you have all that. SRT is always a gamble, but for most men the downside to the gamble is greatly outweighed by the upside of a potential cure.

Posts.Title: New to Forum

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dunbar Hi all and thanks so much for your responses. Just two questions Replicant - hope you dont mind: 1. Why did you select the treatment you had - any specific reason? 2. Did your (our) age limit the sideeffects? I will definitely research as much as I can regarding surgens for my selected treatment. Great advise about the number of procedures ThatBiopsyHurt - thanks! I am quite comfortable with my hospital - St Vincents, Sydney - however really need to find the best surgeon there. Are they happy to give me the numbers, statistics etc? Really don't want to upset the guy who is cutting me open.... Thanks again Dunbar Hi Dunbar. In response to your questions to me: 1.) I have to admit, I'm a bit of a geek and I was attracted to the technology of the Da Vinci robot, which was pretty new at the time--and not even installed at my hospital yet. It sounded like it would be a lot easier to undergo than traditional surgery. My urologist was enthusiastic about it. Unfortunately, he was very low on the learning curve, and that might (I can never know for sure) account for my positive surgical margin, post-surgery rising PSA, and need for radiation. As for why surgery...being 43, I wanted something that had a very well-known, established track record, and the prostatectomy certainly fit that bill. I was also influenced by the idea that if it failed, salvage radiation probably wouldn't be a huge deal. On the other hand, if I went with radiation first, a salvage prostatectomy would be a very tricky prospect with high rates of serious side effects. With the passage of time, I'm not sure that's such a compelling reason. For example, in my case, if I had done radiation first, maybe it would have wiped out all the cancer and I would not have had to deal with the (possible) surgeon's error and positive margin. Maybe the argument about being able to do radiation after surgery but not vice versa only *seems* to hold water because so many surgeons fail to get it all, leaving a need for radiation to mop up the remnants. There's no way to know for sure. And in hindsight, the external radiation was far, far easier than the surgery. I *hated* the foley catheter, and was depressed the whole time I was in the hospital. The surgery took 7 or 8 hours (normally a Da Vinci takes half that) because my surgeon was being proctored by a Mayo surgeon, and advised by a company rep from the Da Vinci manufacturer. So they were moving very cautiously. As a result, I was under general for a long time, and when I woke up, I felt terrible and for a minute didn't remember what had happened. I thought I might be dying, in fact. ("You're not dying, you're in recovery", said a nurse. "He's a glass half-empty type", said my wife.) I had never had major surgery before, and make no mistake--this is major surgery, even when done laparoscopically and with a robot. 2.) I think my relative youth helped. Being young with prostate cancer is a double-edged sword. On the one hand, being young can help you recover sexual function faster and to a greater degree, if you have surgery and the surgeon can spare the nerves. It probably also helps with urinary continence. On the other hand, you have a lot of time for a recurrence, and a lot of time for the cancer to kill you if you do have a recurrence. The median age at diagnosis is 67, according to SEER data. The average lifespan for a man in the U.S. is 75. So take a guy who's 67. He has surgery, and three years later, his PSA starts to rise. It usually takes several years for a biochemical recurrence to develop into detectable mets. And then a few years after that to cause death, assuming he doesn't do hormone therapy. But he probably would. And taxotere, provenge, etc after that. So the odds that he's going to die from prostate cancer rather than with it are pretty slim. Now take a guy who's 43--like you and me (at diagnosis). If our PSA rises within a few years, and let's say salvage radiation fails to cure--time is not on our side. If we don't do anything else, PCa will probably kill us before a heart attack or stroke, the usual way men die in the US. Even if we do start hormone therapy, and even if it does work, it's not likely to work long enough (in our young states) to be "as good as" a cure, like it is for a lot of older patients. So in a nutshell, yes, I think my youth helped. I'm doing very well in terms of continence and pretty well in the bedroom. But I always have in the back of my mind that if my PSA starts to rise anytime soon, I will be in serious trouble. My dad, on the other hand was treated successfully with cryo about 20 years ago. At his age (80) now, he can forget about PSA testing. Believe it or not, up until just now he's been getting an annual PSA *and* DRE. Ugh. If it starts to rise now, it's very, very unlikely to get him before his heart does.

Posts.Title: So I got PCa - now what?

Posts.Content: Our stats are very similar. I was 43, had 3+4=7 for Gleason, and my PSA wasn't a whole lot different. That's not to say that my course of action (Da Vinci) is what you should do. It might be, it might not. I would find the very best surgeon you can reasonably travel to. If he does robotic, fine--go robotic. If he does open surgery, do that. Go for the surgeon, not the technique, is what I'm saying. You probably have all the other options available to you as well. My understanding is that overall, radiation including brachytherapy and exernal beam, are comparable to surgery in terms of long term control or cure. But for younger patients--like those of us under 50--surgery has a slight statistical edge in the long term. But after evaluating your options, you decide you don't want surgery, then don't do it. I think Walsh's book is excellent, and although he's a surgeon, he doesn't advocate surgery across the board. The new patient's guide on the Prostate Cancer Foundation website is very helpful. If you're interested in seeds, you should get a second opinion from the best brachy guy in your area. Same with external beam. If you are confident in your robotic guy, and he's at a top hospital, and he has done lots (hundreds) of Da Vinci procedures and is getting good results in terms of surgical margins, I wouldn't be overly anxious about it. That route sounds fine to me. Just make sure you understand the pros and cons of all your options before committing. There's no need to rush. Best wishes. Lots of men have been down this road before you, and lots are walking alongside you right now, all over the world. There's no reason to think this won't be anything but a bump in the road.

Posts.Title: My first muster onboard

Posts.Content: notme, from the website you linked to, I went into the diagnosis section. Indeed, this site is NOT claiming that MRI can diagnose prostate cancer. As I wrote in the other response, the site is talking about using MRI to avoid blind biopsies, to target where the needle goes. Quote from site (emphasis supplied by me) Diagnosis Prostate cancer is most often discovered by physical examination or by screening blood tests, such as the PSA (prostate specific antigen) test. Suspected prostate cancer is typically confirmed by removing a piece of the prostate (biopsy) and examining it under a microscope. However, blind needle biopsies spread cancer cells and only yield a 25 % success rate in finding cancer. Recent advancements in imaging technology such as prostate 3.0 Tesla MRI with Spectroscopy allow physicians to locate suspicious areas of disease and then performed targeted biopsies improving diagnostic outcomes by up to 40%. In addition to locating suspicious lesions, 3.0 Tesla with Spectroscopy can determine whether prostate cancer has spread beyond the capsule. http://www.mrisusa.com/Prostate%20Cancer.html

Posts.Content: Our stats are very similar. I was 43, had 3+4=7 for Gleason, and my PSA wasn't a whole lot different. That's not to say that my course of action (Da Vinci) is what you should do. It might be, it might not. I would find the very best surgeon you can reasonably travel to. If he does robotic, fine--go robotic. If he does open surgery, do that. Go for the surgeon, not the technique, is what I'm saying. You probably have all the other options available to you as well. My understanding is that overall, radiation including brachytherapy and exernal beam, are comparable to surgery in terms of long term control or cure. But for younger patients--like those of us under 50--surgery has a slight statistical edge in the long term. But after evaluating your options, you decide you don't want surgery, then don't do it. I think Walsh's book is excellent, and although he's a surgeon, he doesn't advocate surgery across the board. The new patient's guide on the Prostate Cancer Foundation website is very helpful. If you're interested in seeds, you should get a second opinion from the best brachy guy in your area. Same with external beam. If you are confident in your robotic guy, and he's at a top hospital, and he has done lots (hundreds) of Da Vinci procedures and is getting good results in terms of surgical margins, I wouldn't be overly anxious about it. That route sounds fine to me. Just make sure you understand the pros and cons of all your options before committing. There's no need to rush. Best wishes. Lots of men have been down this road before you, and lots are walking alongside you right now, all over the world. There's no reason to think this won't be anything but a bump in the road.

Posts.Content: Walsh is also a believer in radiation over surgery for patients 70 and over, according to his book. On page 240 he says the ideal radical prostatectomy patient is under 70, and the ideal radiation therapy patient is over 60 (but later he says that radiation is a valid choice for men of any age). On page 243, he says surgery "is not ideal for older patients." He likes radiation for all stages, while he recommends surgery for T1b, T1c, T2, and some T1a patients. (p. 240). He goes on to say (p. 243) that age is a factor because men over 70 often have cancer that is more advanced than the biopsy would lead the doctor to believe initially, and less likely to be curable, because it's been growing longer. He also doesn't like the fact that surgical side effects get worse the older the patient is at the time of surgery. Finally, and remember who's talking here (the best known prostate surgeon) on page 244 he says "because men over age 70 aren't likely to live as long as men twenty years younger, it's difficult to show that radical prostatectomy actually does more than radiation therapy to lengthen life expectancy in these men." I highly recommend Walsh's book, "Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" (2007 ed.)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dunbar Hi all and thanks so much for your responses. Just two questions Replicant - hope you dont mind: 1. Why did you select the treatment you had - any specific reason? 2. Did your (our) age limit the sideeffects? I will definitely research as much as I can regarding surgens for my selected treatment. Great advise about the number of procedures ThatBiopsyHurt - thanks! I am quite comfortable with my hospital - St Vincents, Sydney - however really need to find the best surgeon there. Are they happy to give me the numbers, statistics etc? Really don't want to upset the guy who is cutting me open.... Thanks again Dunbar Hi Dunbar. In response to your questions to me: 1.) I have to admit, I'm a bit of a geek and I was attracted to the technology of the Da Vinci robot, which was pretty new at the time--and not even installed at my hospital yet. It sounded like it would be a lot easier to undergo than traditional surgery. My urologist was enthusiastic about it. Unfortunately, he was very low on the learning curve, and that might (I can never know for sure) account for my positive surgical margin, post-surgery rising PSA, and need for radiation. As for why surgery...being 43, I wanted something that had a very well-known, established track record, and the prostatectomy certainly fit that bill. I was also influenced by the idea that if it failed, salvage radiation probably wouldn't be a huge deal. On the other hand, if I went with radiation first, a salvage prostatectomy would be a very tricky prospect with high rates of serious side effects. With the passage of time, I'm not sure that's such a compelling reason. For example, in my case, if I had done radiation first, maybe it would have wiped out all the cancer and I would not have had to deal with the (possible) surgeon's error and positive margin. Maybe the argument about being able to do radiation after surgery but not vice versa only *seems* to hold water because so many surgeons fail to get it all, leaving a need for radiation to mop up the remnants. There's no way to know for sure. And in hindsight, the external radiation was far, far easier than the surgery. I *hated* the foley catheter, and was depressed the whole time I was in the hospital. The surgery took 7 or 8 hours (normally a Da Vinci takes half that) because my surgeon was being proctored by a Mayo surgeon, and advised by a company rep from the Da Vinci manufacturer. So they were moving very cautiously. As a result, I was under general for a long time, and when I woke up, I felt terrible and for a minute didn't remember what had happened. I thought I might be dying, in fact. ("You're not dying, you're in recovery", said a nurse. "He's a glass half-empty type", said my wife.) I had never had major surgery before, and make no mistake--this is major surgery, even when done laparoscopically and with a robot. 2.) I think my relative youth helped. Being young with prostate cancer is a double-edged sword. On the one hand, being young can help you recover sexual function faster and to a greater degree, if you have surgery and the surgeon can spare the nerves. It probably also helps with urinary continence. On the other hand, you have a lot of time for a recurrence, and a lot of time for the cancer to kill you if you do have a recurrence. The median age at diagnosis is 67, according to SEER data. The average lifespan for a man in the U.S. is 75. So take a guy who's 67. He has surgery, and three years later, his PSA starts to rise. It usually takes several years for a biochemical recurrence to develop into detectable mets. And then a few years after that to cause death, assuming he doesn't do hormone therapy. But he probably would. And taxotere, provenge, etc after that. So the odds that he's going to die from prostate cancer rather than with it are pretty slim. Now take a guy who's 43--like you and me (at diagnosis). If our PSA rises within a few years, and let's say salvage radiation fails to cure--time is not on our side. If we don't do anything else, PCa will probably kill us before a heart attack or stroke, the usual way men die in the US. Even if we do start hormone therapy, and even if it does work, it's not likely to work long enough (in our young states) to be "as good as" a cure, like it is for a lot of older patients. So in a nutshell, yes, I think my youth helped. I'm doing very well in terms of continence and pretty well in the bedroom. But I always have in the back of my mind that if my PSA starts to rise anytime soon, I will be in serious trouble. My dad, on the other hand was treated successfully with cryo about 20 years ago. At his age (80) now, he can forget about PSA testing. Believe it or not, up until just now he's been getting an annual PSA *and* DRE. Ugh. If it starts to rise now, it's very, very unlikely to get him before his heart does.

My understanding is that overall, radiation including brachytherapy and exernal beam, are comparable to surgery in terms of long term control or cure. But for younger patients--like those of us under 50--surgery has a slight statistical edge in the long term. But after evaluating your options, you decide you don't want surgery, then don't do it. I think Walsh's book is excellent, and although he's a surgeon, he doesn't advocate surgery across the board. The new patient's guide on the Prostate Cancer Foundation website is very helpful. If you're interested in seeds, you should get a second opinion from the best brachy guy in your area. Same with external beam. If you are confident in your robotic guy, and he's at a top hospital, and he has done lots (hundreds) of Da Vinci procedures and is getting good results in terms of surgical margins, I wouldn't be overly anxious about it. That route sounds fine to me. Just make sure you understand the pros and cons of all your options before committing. There's no need to rush. Best wishes. Lots of men have been down this road before you, and lots are walking alongside you right now, all over the world. There's no reason to think this won't be anything but a bump in the road.

The surgery took 7 or 8 hours (normally a Da Vinci takes half that) because my surgeon was being proctored by a Mayo surgeon, and advised by a company rep from the Da Vinci manufacturer. So they were moving very cautiously. As a result, I was under general for a long time, and when I woke up, I felt terrible and for a minute didn't remember what had happened. I thought I might be dying, in fact. ("You're not dying, you're in recovery", said a nurse. "He's a glass half-empty type", said my wife.) I had never had major surgery before, and make no mistake--this is major surgery, even when done laparoscopically and with a robot. 2.) I think my relative youth helped. Being young with prostate cancer is a double-edged sword. On the one hand, being young can help you recover sexual function faster and to a greater degree, if you have surgery and the surgeon can spare the nerves. It probably also helps with urinary continence. On the other hand, you have a lot of time for a recurrence, and a lot of time for the cancer to kill you if you do have a recurrence. The median age at diagnosis is 67, according to SEER data. The average lifespan for a man in the U.S. is 75. So take a guy who's 67. He has surgery, and three years later, his PSA starts to rise. It usually takes several years for a biochemical recurrence to develop into detectable mets. And then a few years after that to cause death, assuming he doesn't do hormone therapy. But he probably would. And taxotere, provenge, etc after that. So the odds that he's going to die from prostate cancer rather than with it are pretty slim. Now take a guy who's 43--like you and me (at diagnosis). If our PSA rises within a few years, and let's say salvage radiation fails to cure--time is not on our side. If we don't do anything else, PCa will probably kill us before a heart attack or stroke, the usual way men die in the US. Even if we do start hormone therapy, and even if it does work, it's not likely to work long enough (in our young states) to be "as good as" a cure, like it is for a lot of older patients. So in a nutshell, yes, I think my youth helped. I'm doing very well in terms of continence and pretty well in the bedroom. But I always have in the back of my mind that if my PSA starts to rise anytime soon, I will be in serious trouble. My dad, on the other hand was treated successfully with cryo about 20 years ago. At his age (80) now, he can forget about PSA testing. Believe it or not, up until just now he's been getting an annual PSA *and* DRE. Ugh. If it starts to rise now, it's very, very unlikely to get him before his heart does.

Great advise about the number of procedures ThatBiopsyHurt - thanks! I am quite comfortable with my hospital - St Vincents, Sydney - however really need to find the best surgeon there. Are they happy to give me the numbers, statistics etc? Really don't want to upset the guy who is cutting me open.... Thanks again Dunbar Hi Dunbar. In response to your questions to me: 1.) I have to admit, I'm a bit of a geek and I was attracted to the technology of the Da Vinci robot, which was pretty new at the time--and not even installed at my hospital yet. It sounded like it would be a lot easier to undergo than traditional surgery. My urologist was enthusiastic about it. Unfortunately, he was very low on the learning curve, and that might (I can never know for sure) account for my positive surgical margin, post-surgery rising PSA, and need for radiation. Posts.Content: I'm not a doctor, of course, but what you describe sounds like prostatitis. It's very unlikely at 27 to be prostate cancer. The specialist to see is a urologist. Best luck to you. Originally Posted by zrisk002 I was looking through a few pages of posts and am having difficulty finding an answer without posting my question... I'm a 27 year old male and I have had prostate issues the last 3 or 4 years. I am urinating frequently, wake up plenty at night to go and also have trouble going. I'm not nervous when urinating, but sometimes I just cant go or I get a few drips out even though I really need to go. Anyways, I felt that could just be mild prostate issues because I'm getting older. Also, once in a while I have intense burning after I go. The reason why I'm posting though today is because a few weeks ago I ejaculated pure blood after having sex with my wife. It wasn't a cut or anything. What does this mean? I don't know what step to take next. I'm pretty concerned after what happened, any advice would be amazing and I appreciate everyone here...

Posts.Content: Walsh is also a believer in radiation over surgery for patients 70 and over, according to his book. On page 240 he says the ideal radical prostatectomy patient is under 70, and the ideal radiation therapy patient is over 60 (but later he says that radiation is a valid choice for men of any age). On page 243, he says surgery "is not ideal for older patients." He likes radiation for all stages, while he recommends surgery for T1b, T1c, T2, and some T1a patients. (p. 240). He goes on to say (p. 243) that age is a factor because men over 70 often have cancer that is more advanced than the biopsy would lead the doctor to believe initially, and less likely to be curable, because it's been growing longer. He also doesn't like the fact that surgical side effects get worse the older the patient is at the time of surgery. Finally, and remember who's talking here (the best known prostate surgeon) on page 244 he says "because men over age 70 aren't likely to live as long as men twenty years younger, it's difficult to show that radical prostatectomy actually does more than radiation therapy to lengthen life expectancy in these men." I highly recommend Walsh's book, "Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" (2007 ed.)
