Posts.Content: Walsh, in his book on pages 178-179, addresses the question of needle tracking of tumor cells. He says "This is an excellent question and a very common fear", but basically if it were a serious risk, then "the whole concept of early diagnosis and treatment wouldn't work. But many thousands of people--all of whom had initial biopsies to confirm what they had--have been cured of cancer." He goes on to say that sometimes cancer cells may escape into the bloodstream, and that the "circulation of cancer cells in the blood is probably a common event, even in cancers that are curable. And it's not unreasonable to assume that a few more cells may find their way into the bloodstream when the tumor is manipulated, as it is during a biopsy. The key is the stage of your cancer. When cancer is confined to the prostate, even if a few cells escape into the blood, they won't survive. This is because they haven't yet got the hang of living outside the area where they developed." A few sentences later: "So there are two different issues. One is the presence of cancer cells in the blood.; the other is the survival of these cells in distant locations. Prostate cancer cells are simply unable to live outside their normal environment until they develop this ability, called metastatic capability."

Posts.Content: notme, from the website you linked to, I went into the diagnosis section. Indeed, this site is NOT claiming that MRI can diagnose prostate cancer. As I wrote in the other response, the site is talking about using MRI to avoid blind biopsies, to target where the needle goes. Quote from site (emphasis supplied by me) Diagnosis Prostate cancer is most often discovered by physical examination or by screening blood tests, such as the PSA (prostate specific antigen) test. Suspected prostate cancer is typically confirmed by removing a piece of the prostate (biopsy) and examining it under a microscope. However, blind needle biopsies spread cancer cells and only yield a 25 % success rate in finding cancer. Recent advancements in imaging technology such as prostate 3.0 Tesla MRI with Spectroscopy allow physicians to locate suspicious areas of disease and then performed targeted biopsies improving diagnostic outcomes by up to 40%. In addition to locating suspicious lesions, 3.0 Tesla with Spectroscopy can determine whether prostate cancer has spread beyond the capsule. http://www.mrisusa.com/Prostate%20Cancer.html

Posts.Title: does prostate biopsy spread cancer?

Posts.Content: MRI does not diagnose prostate cancer. A pathologist needs to look at the cells under a microscope. MRIs can be used to look for spread outside the prostate, and there may be a role in using it to do targeted needle biopsies. My reading of the literature (on the National Library of Science's PubMed, for example) is that the risk of a biopsy needle tracking tumor cells into healthy tissue is not zero, but it is on the order of a few percent. A 1991 study by Walsh and Epstein at Johns Hopkins found that 2% or so of their biopsies showed evidence of this--but this was back when needles were bigger. There is also the risk of infection, even though this risk is mitigated by antibiotics. (A friend of our family had a quite serious infection from a prostate biopsy). Therefore, prostate biopsies should not be done without reasonable suspicion. The risk needs to be balanced against the benefit of the information gained. Just my non-qualified view on the matter.

Posts.Content: 1. I've never seen a drawing like that, but maybe the oval is your bladder? Just a guess. 2. Negative, or clear margins, refer to surgery pathology. The pathologist looks at the removed tissue in slices. If he sees cancer right up to the cut edge of the removed tissue, that's a positive margin. If tumor cells go up to the very edge of the removed tissue, that increases the chances that some cancer was left behind. But it's not a guarantee that happened. For example, Dr. Walsh explains, the clear margin could have been very thin, and it it got sort of rubbed off after the prostate was removed. Damaged during handling, in other words. The significance of this is, if your PSA starts going up after surgery, and you had positive margins, then you have a logical, *local* explanation for the PSA--and if it's only in that area where your prostate was, you may still be cured by salvage radiation. That's apparently what happened in my situation. On the other hand, if you have clear, or negative margins after surgery, that's a good sign that the surgeon did "get it all", although it's not bombproof by any means. Some cells could have escaped. As to your bigger question about active surveillance-it is an option for some men. My uncle, for example, has been doing it for years now, and is doing fine. He'll most likely die with prostate cancer, not from it, and he won't have to put up with any treatments or side effects. Of course he's having to put up with periodic PSA tests, DREs, and biopsies. It's not an option for everyone, of course. I was at the other end of the spectrum--Gleason 7, rapidly increasing PSA, and only 43 years old. If I hadn't acted, I'm pretty sure I would be dying a painful death right about now. I would echo the advice: take your time, do your research, and make a carefully considered decision. I personally like Walsh's book, although it's getting a little dated. Also, the Prostate Cancer Foundation has a lot of good info on their website. Here's what they say about active surveillance: "Today, the man who is ideal for active surveillance has a low grade (Gleason 6 or under), low-risk prostate cancer (low PSA and stage), that appears to be low in volume (small amount of cancer found on biopsy, for example), and who is not eager to undergo therapy right away due to concerns about potency preservation or urinary symptoms. Active surveillance might also be a good choice for older men with limited life expectancy. In addition, if a man is currently battling other serious disorders or diseases, such as heart disease, long-standing high blood pressure, or poorly controlled diabetes, his doctors might feel it is in his best interest to hold off on therapy and avoid its potential complications. That’s because many of the treatment options for prostate cancer can be difficult to endure, and better outcomes are seen in men who are otherwise healthy." http://www.pcf.org/site/c.leJRIROrEp...rveillance.htm Best wishes! Originally Posted by dshinnick 1. In the results of my biopsy, in the little drawing showing the 12 tested sections of the prostate, in the upper center is a dark oval which they don't identify. I don't think it's cancer-related, but inquiring minds want to know...what is that? 2. Folks refer to "negative margins" or "clear margins". What's that? Thoughts? Thanks- Dave

Posts.Title: Coupla questions

Posts.Content: 1. I've never seen a drawing like that, but maybe the oval is your bladder? Just a guess. 2. Negative, or clear margins, refer to surgery pathology. The pathologist looks at the removed tissue in slices. If he sees cancer right up to the cut edge of the removed tissue, that's a positive margin. If tumor cells go up to the very edge of the removed tissue, that increases the chances that some cancer was left behind. But it's not a guarantee that happened. For example, Dr. Walsh explains, the clear margin could have been very thin, and it it got sort of rubbed off after the prostate was removed. Damaged during handling, in other words. The significance of this is, if your PSA starts going up after surgery, and you had positive margins, then you have a logical, *local* explanation for the PSA--and if it's only in that area where your prostate was, you may still be cured by salvage radiation. That's apparently what happened in my situation. On the other hand, if you have clear, or negative margins after surgery, that's a good sign that the surgeon did "get it all", although it's not bombproof by any means. Some cells could have escaped. As to your bigger question about active surveillance-it is an option for some men. My uncle, for example, has been doing it for years now, and is doing fine. He'll most likely die with prostate cancer, not from it, and he won't have to put up with any treatments or side effects. Of course he's having to put up with periodic PSA tests, DREs, and biopsies. It's not an option for everyone, of course. I was at the other end of the spectrum--Gleason 7, rapidly increasing PSA, and only 43 years old. If I hadn't acted, I'm pretty sure I would be dying a painful death right about now. I would echo the advice: take your time, do your research, and make a carefully considered decision. I personally like Walsh's book, although it's getting a little dated. Also, the Prostate Cancer Foundation has a lot of good info on their website. Here's what they say about active surveillance: "Today, the man who is ideal for active surveillance has a low grade (Gleason 6 or under), low-risk prostate cancer (low PSA and stage), that appears to be low in volume (small amount of cancer found on biopsy, for example), and who is not eager to undergo therapy right away due to concerns about potency preservation or urinary symptoms. Active surveillance might also be a good choice for older men with limited life expectancy. In addition, if a man is currently battling other serious disorders or diseases, such as heart disease, long-standing high blood pressure, or poorly controlled diabetes, his doctors might feel it is in his best interest to hold off on therapy and avoid its potential complications. That’s because many of the treatment options for prostate cancer can be difficult to endure, and better outcomes are seen in men who are otherwise healthy." http://www.pcf.org/site/c.leJRIROrEp...rveillance.htm Best wishes! Originally Posted by dshinnick 1. In the results of my biopsy, in the little drawing showing the 12 tested sections of the prostate, in the upper center is a dark oval which they don't identify. I don't think it's cancer-related, but inquiring minds want to know...what is that? 2. Folks refer to "negative margins" or "clear margins". What's that? Thoughts? Thanks- Dave

Posts.Title: Post Salvage RT PSA Update

Posts.Content: Ha! I'm a lurker these days. I was wondering how you're doing! It looks like very, very well. Good to see! I'll have another PSA in a couple of months, but at last check I was still less than 0.1. My radiation oncologist released me from his care, since it had been 5 years, and I'll just get a PSA along with my other blood work (cholesterol) every 6 months or annually. Originally Posted by Hawk Hope from salvage radiation I thought I would post a quick note just to document that there is hope for those with Gleason 8 and a pre-surgical PSA of 16 even when the cancer returns after having clean surgical margins. I had SRT 3 ½ years ago and just got a PSA of 0.02 It took 24 months to bottom out at that reading and has been steady there for 18 months. I have to say I am a bit pleasantly surprised. I went 18 months between my last 2 PSA tests because I lived from test to test every 3 to 6 months for 6 years and just got tired of it. I figured at this stage there is no rush for hormone therapy if the PSA started back up anyway so why not just focus on other stuff for a while. Pre-surgery 16.6 and 8.7 Pre SRT .16 Post SRT .10 3 month .09 6 month .06 9 month .04 12 month .04 18 month .03 24 month .02 42 month .02 Hawk PS: I see my old friend and mentor Replicant has not been on for a few weeks

Posts.Title: Post Salvage RT PSA Update

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by chasgrips45 So step 2 in my little journey. I hate the term Salvage radiation ,but i guess that`s what it was. During the treatment ,I had minimal side effects . Pooper a little sore, continence about the same. The worst was the urge to get up 7 times a night to pee. So today is Friday, & I`m as weak as a kitten,& have a hell of a headache. The doc gave me a little better than a 50% chance of a cure. Bad #8 Gleason . I lasted for a year before a rise in psa. I hope I`m wrong ,but here`s the way this thing plays out IMHO . I probably go for a while with a zero psa ,after the initial bump. It`s then the 3 mo waiting game for the psa test . How long before it returns,maybe 5 yrs, tops. I then hope that the doubling time is slow. No hormones. I sure as hell don`t need my mood to get any lower! I had no idea that AFTER the radiation ,I would feel so tired . Maybe I`ll go back for more to get my strength back! I`m not sitting on the pity pot it`s just that I hope this process is for naught. I feel like i`m in a fog ,I`ve got to rest. The side effects should resolve on their own within several weeks of finishing treatment. I hope your results are as good as mine. Salvage radiation really paid off for me.

Posts.Content: Rich, I agree with the others that it's pretty unlikely you have prostate cancer (especially advanced prostate cancer) at age 29, and it's much more likely that you have something else or multiple something elses that are causing your discomforts. Some of the things you describe sound a lot like prostatitis (inflammation of the prostate, often caused by infection). If you do have prostatitis, if it's caused by a bacterial infection then antibiotics should take care of it, although the doc might have to try more than one type. If it's more chronic, and not bacterial, I think the doctor would go after the symptom of inflammation by treating you with some powerful anti-inflammatory medication, like high dosage Motrin. Insomnia can actually cause night time urination, or at least it does in my case. I'm a light sleeper, and easily disturbed, which triggers the urge to go to the loo in the middle of the night. If I take a simple sleep aid, like doxylamine succinate (Unisom) I'll sleep all night. Cheap, too, at WalMart in the Equate version. Lately I've used melatonin, which seems to help me sleep more naturally (and it helps with the getting up to pee thing, too.) And like someone else wrote, the back pain definitely sounds like a regular old back problem, not metastatic cancer. If you want to scratch prostate cancer off your worry list, get a PSA test and DRE (not fun, but it only takes a few moments). If I were you, I'd concentrate on trying to improve your quality of sleep, and see how the rest of your health improves after that. The moderator on another board used this as her signature: "Worry is like a rocking chair. It gives you something to do, but gets you nowhere." I wish you health and peace of mind.

AgeInfo.Phrase: advanced prostate cancer  at age 29  and it's much more likely

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Does chemo have a better record? Until recently, chemo had a very poor record against prostate cancer. In 1997 Johns Hopkins University said "So far, standard chemotherapy hasn't worked in prostate cancer. Not only does it fail to cure cancer, it doesn't prolong survival to any significant degree, and it sometimes harsh side effects can make an unpleasant situation even worse." (http://urology.jhu.edu/newsletter/pr..._cancer419.php) Since then, there have been many developments on the chemo front, with the first significant development being taxotere. Then there is Provenge, which is an immune-based therapy. Zytiga is a drug that can come after standard hormone therapy and before chemo. But as far as I know, hormone therapy is normally the first line of defense after curative attempts have failed, because it can be extremely effective in many cases. (A friend of my father's had the surgical equivalent of hormone therapy, and it completely stalled his prostate cancer and eliminated symptoms for about 8 years.) Chemo seems to be reserved for hormone-refractory (sometimes called hormone-resistant or castration independent) metastatic prostate cancer. The drugs can extend survival, but not as dramatically as hormone therapy. My understanding is that traditional chemo is most effective against fast-dividing cells. Compared to other cancers, prostate cancer cells are slow-dividers, so chemo is not as effective against PCa. The American Cancer Society says: "In most cases, the first chemo drug given is docetaxel, combined with the steroid drug prednisone. If this drug does not work (or stops working), a newer drug called cabazitaxel is often the next chemo drug tried (although there may be other treatment options as well). Both of these drugs have been shown to help men live several months longer, on average, than older chemotherapy drugs. They may slow the cancer's growth and also reduce symptoms, resulting in a better quality of life. Still, chemotherapy for prostate cancer is very unlikely to result in a cure." So in a nutshell (and maybe Az4peaks or someone else can elaborate or correct me) my understanding is that there have been improvements in chemo for prostate cancer, but the survival gains are modest so the first line of treatment in metastatic PCa is hormone therapy, followed by chemo.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lancepeace There is quite a bit of controversy about when it get hormone therapy after recurrence. Walsh and some others suggest there is no hurry to start hormone therapy which works on androgen dependent cancer. Lupron shots for example do not seem to work on androgen independent cancer. I have heard of hormone therapy working for as long as 10 years and as few as 3 months so it varies a lot. That's my understanding as well. I have read Walsh and his argument seems sound. However, I have also seen a study that showed early hormone therapy was better than late in men with fast PSA doubling times. My own doubling time was rapid, so I have decided to pursue HT pretty quickly if my PSA rises. I have my medical oncologist picked out and have checked to make sure he takes my insurance.

Posts.Content: Speaking as myself, not as a moderator, I think: HIFU is a great, promising treatment. I think in a few years it will be very popular in the U.S., and many men with early or intermediate risk cancer will go for HIFU instead of surgery or radiation, and for many of those men, HIFU will be successful. (I self-edited this so that the posting was about the treatment, and not a continuation of the argument--Rep.)

Posts.Content: I had some mild spasms before and after catheter removal, but nothing like that! My urologist had prescribed antispasmodics in the hospital and sent me home with some. If I had a good twinge, I'd pop a pill. Hope it's much better after the catheter comes out again--I bet it will.

DoctorRecommended.Sample: Finally, and remember who's talking here (the best known prostate surgeon) on page 244 he says "because men over age 70 aren't likely to live as long as men twenty years younger, it's difficult to show that radical prostatectomy actually does more than radiation therapy to lengthen life expectancy in these men." I highly recommend Walsh's book, "Dr....That would be a good question for a radiation oncologist, and should your husband be diagnosed, I would definitely consult one in addition to the urologist and a medical oncologist. If he has a biopsy, and if it is positive for cancer, it will provide valuable information that will help the physician(s) estimate clinical stage and recommend appropriate treatment....
